39310556.review:
A fast-paced, strategic 2D undead murder simulator: put the undead back in their place!

The pressure on your quick-aim reflex and constant weapon juggling involved makes DEADBOLT feel a lot like Hotline Miami; it puts you in the same kind of murder-zen once you get rolling, so if you liked Hotline 1 and/or 2, you'll like DEADBOLT.  Whereas Hotline is a pure aggressive bloodbath, DEADBOLT is a hit-and-run game that involves hiding in shadows (sinister 'click' as the lights go out), moving through vents as smoke, ducking behind cover, and using doors to lure or separate enemies (knock knock!).  Hopoo Games is the developer, meaning that the art and music here vaguely resemble Risk of Rain - except that the artists and composer have improved since then (go listen to "Now I Am Become Death" from the OST if you need convincing).  I recommend saving up for the Scythe.  Bringing the Flashbang with help you enter rooms with multiple ranged enemies, meaning it has good synergy with the Scythe.  Death & Taxes are cool dual-wield pistols.

The game is "short" (I beat it in 7 hours, with about 2 hours of experimental level attempts like 'melee only' or 'pure stealth'), but the hard mode (2nd playthrough) adds extra enemies to each level, and changes their positions: this is significant, because ammo is scarce and the first playthrough was already difficult.  Hard mode will test your accuracy (headshots -> extra damage -> conserved ammo) and force you to create a different strategy from the one that worked during your first playthrough.  In addition to the well-made hard mode, there is a level editor, allowing the community to make its own levels.  This gives the game additional longevity for people who enjoy the tense gameplay.

If you like speedrunning, there are also special achievements for beating the game quickly, and for beating it without dying: these achievements give you bonus Spirits to spend on extra weapons to buff out your file.  My recommendation is not to think about rank and achievements on your first run: go hard, and focus on getting good.  You'll still be able to afford probably 4 or 5 guns for the trunk without trying too hard, so you'll have a few favorites that you can bring into any level.

39087205.review:
TL;DR It's pretty good but it does get a bit repetitive over time (~5 hours for me but it's not to the point of not wanting to play it anymore, it's just less satisfying), it's not very innovative or anything but everything it does is done right or mostly right. 

My first and main (only?) complaint is that it could do with one more button:
E does a shit ton of things including pick up weapons (if you already have 2 it will swap the equipped one with the one on the floor) so it will happen frequently that you can't open a door because there's a gun on the floor. You can work your way out of it but it's still annoying and quite unfair.

The ennemies will always kill you in one shot (it take can take a lot more for you depending on the ennemy and the gun) but you can see them at any time (unless they're out of the screen) and move through vents while they can't so it's still balanced.

Every ennemy is fundamentally different which is really cool.

I like how there are many ways to complete every mission especially after the first couple of hours that are a bit more linear. It makes the game a bit harder but also a lot more interesting.

The music is great, very groovy and it's almost always diegetic music (the music exists inside the game's levels) which is handled very well.

I don't really understand their choice to have flashing lights in some levels, you can disable it so it's ok but it's such a strange and annoying thing in the first place, it doesn't add anything to the gameplay either.

I think 10€ is an OK price if you like this type of game but you can always add it to your wishlist if you're unsure.

+:

-:
[list]

    [*] sometimes getting into cover, opening closing doors or moving into vents is a bit fiddly in fast paced moments
    [*] on first launch the game would not show up in the taskbar (Windows) and I needed to [i]ALT+TAB[/i] into the game and press [i]ALT+ENTER[/i] to toggle fullscreen, which was a bit confusing.
[/list]

(This review only discusses gameplay) Deadbolt truly one of the best indie games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. I know people have likely said this before but this game mimics that gameplay style of hotline miami and gunpoint (Play gunpoint pls) albeit with more strategy involved and what I believe to be more skill. As the reapers mentioned in the summary of the game you have the ability to go through vents and toilets using a lighter and turning into what I can only assume is ash or smoke. This allows you to go through missions\levels in many different ways. Equipment in this game can be from difficult to use melee weapons to a silenced pistol and rifle to a shotgun and a knife. Meaning you can "stealth" without "detection" which I will say loosely because I had lots of trouble doing it. Enemies all have different ways to be attacked such as how the fat zombies can't be meleed most of the time and vampires are tall and have more health requiring to mostly headshot while at the same time fighting zombies who are shorter and easier to kill. I recommend this game greatly and think everyone should beat hard mode before they say anything about the game.

38777866.review:
Deadbolt is a 2D stealth-action sidescroller where you are an undead hitman tasked with killing zombies, vampires, and other supernatural horrors.

The Good:
+The soundtrack is a great low-key mix of jazzy blues tunes.
+Addictive gameplay of planning routes and quickly killing enemies.
+Good mix of maps and enemies types.
+The story is macabre and vague, but it works with the setting.

The Bad:
-Short length, but there are challenges and user-generated content if you really want to play more.
-Aim and movement can feel finnicky.
-Unlock system is somewhat token.

The Bottom Line:
Deadbolt is a fun little game, which should entertain you for about 5 hours. However, some might find the full asking price a little much for the content.

38460168.review:
DEADBOLT plays like a seamless combination of Gunpoint and Hotline Miami. Break into a building, kill everything, get out quickly. One hit and you immediately restart the level. The gameplay is very fast-paced, whether you decide to sneak through quietly or charge through the doors killing anything in your path.

The game has a deep story, that although a little hard to follow, is evident if you look for it.

Chris Christodoulou made the soundtrack, (If you've played Risk of Rain, you should be familiar with his work), and it's arguably his best work. Chill jazzy tunes, club trance, metal, the themes are all over the place, but all of the songs are great.

38259966.review: Really, don't have much to say here that the intro vidoes don't already cover. First of all, the aesthetics, visual design and sound are all terrifically on point in a way that makes the creative world feel alive and makes what is a well designed game a lot more compelling. Secondly, the gameplay is excellent, striking a good balance between stealth and action, and blasting someone's head off with a bolt action rifle or slicing someone up with a sythe feels nice and satisfying. If you've played hotline miami, I can definitely say that there's a similar level of intensity to the combat in this game when it does break out. Overall, this game strikes me as very similar to a more polished, action oriented version of "Gunpoint", if that comparison means anything to you. My qualms with this game are very minor: First of all, you can't commit suicide in an airvent to restart the mission, and it takes you half a second to enter the vents. That's not a problem in and of itself, but during the transition it looks like you're taking the form of some incorporeal smoke, and you don't realize that you're vulnerable. That's easily forgiven in my book however, because the game overall is terrific, and the developers really know how to skate the line between being challenging but not inaccessibly or pointlessly hard. Looking foreward to their next project!

As someone who's usually not a fan of horrifically difficult pixel games, I was pleasantly surprised by how fun this game was (and still is!). It's still very playable for someone who's admittedly not the best at video games, but still offers a brutal challenge to those who'd want it; just check the achievements and you'll see what I mean. Even if you aren't an achievement hunter, this game is still challenging in a really fun way, and I would reccomend it to anyone, regardless of skill level (you WILL get better with each try, believe me).

The gameplay is pretty similar to Hotline Miami, but less fast-paced and more tactical. The vent system provides a fun twist, as well as the opportunity to both scope out the level before engaging with enemies and the ability to experiment with many different approaches. Though most levels have an approximate "correct" path that you will eventually figure out, carrying out that path is very difficult and full of little blanks that you can fill in with your own choices.

The settings, characters, and music are all designed/written extremely well, so if you're into video game soundtracks and film noir/mafia movie aesthetics you will enjoy what this game has to offer. The premise is understandable and still unique and consistently interesting as new information is revealed, so don't worry about getting bored with the game as you progress.

The only thing I could say I disliked was the stillness of the docks/the reaper's room, as nothing really ever changes/developes there (except for the addition of the cat, which was adorable). However, I am not completely finished with the game (though I am close) so I may be wrong about that specifically.

37829347.review:
In Deadbolt you play as a sort of Undead hitman: a Reaper. You've been contracted by a strange entity to end the non-lives of the many undead who have been appearing lately.

Deadbolt's gameplay is interestinging and challenging, without being too hard. For the people who want a challenge there's the Conquest achievement that requires you to clear the entire game in under an hour without dying. I'd say it's a strategy game with elements of combat when it comes to aiming and damage vs health (on enemies). Additionally, it has an interesting and thought-provoking, although not very fleshed-out, story. The music is composed by Chris Christodoulou and is among the best soundtracks I've ever heard.
It also allows the players to create their own maps, although I haven't made or tried any of these.

The game mechanics are quite simple:
Light and sound helps enemies detect your position. In many cases there is no need to kill every enemy, so as long as you can get away you'll have succesfully completed a mission. There are light that can be toggled or destroyed, as well as different alarms that work as distractions. Even doors can be used strategically!
Different pipes can be used as a sort of quick travel or to hide from enemies. These become essential to use in later missions.
Different weapons have different specialities. Other than the more casual handguns they can be melee, silent, explosive or inflict large amounts of damage to the enemies.
You can take cover behind certain objects, or just hide behind a door and hope a stray bullet doesn't hit you! The pipes I mentioned earlier can also be used for escaping demise.
You are rewarded with souls after each mission based on your performance, and will also get souls from getting achievements. Souls can be used to purchase additional weapons. This is probably the weakest part of the game since you never really get to try them all in one run due to the cost being too high, but this wasn't really a problem for me.

Every stage is unique and many of them require repeated tries to be completed. The game is split into three parts with different themes, alternating between different types of fiends. While you progress through them you slowly get closer to a sort of undead conspiracy, and I absolutely love the ending story-wise.

37806244.review:
I have put in dozens of hours into DEADBOLT and that says something about its pixelated charm. I will spare you the plot and details of the game but considering the gameplay, content, and difficulty it is worth every penny. In these short statements, DEADBOLT offers a tense, thrilling and consistent experience in btoh combat and atmosphere, combined with a killer soundtrack that caters a range of palettes.

One immediate and striking observation, DEADBOLT does not offer a "choice" of difficulty. Instead the difficulty is rooted in player skill and planning. With only one hit being able to swiftly dispatch your (short) life, DEADBOLT teaches you to be fast, clever, and efficent in managing limited ammo and knowing the variety of foes that have their own weapons and quirks. Mistakes can cost you dearly but clearing out a crowded level with a bloodstained scythe and a empty gun feels rewarding. Therefore, it is not for the easily fustrated as the patient will overcome all levels with enough skill and planning. One final note is that when you beat the campaign, a "Hard" mode is unlocked, offering more enemies to clear out the campaign.

With the DEADBOLT workshop, many users have created their own levels with the accompanying packaged level editor. They vary in quality and how hard (or easy) each custom level presents. However, if you get through the campaign in both "Normal" and "Hard" modes then I suggest playing two user-custom stories: DEADBOLT: Last Stand and FLATLINE. They offer a substanial increase in difficulty, but hopefully with your sharpened knife and even sharper wits they give a fresh, non-canocial insight into the world of DEADBOLT. 

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Do you want to play it? That is up to you.

37793020.review:
8/10

DEADBOLT (I guess I should stick to all caps if the game does) is a 2D stealth-action title in which you play the Grim Reaper. I can't say I totally grasped what's happening with the story, but it seemed to me that I was putting down creatures who were still alive after their allotted time, such as zombies, vampires, and skeletons.

Although at first I found the game almost too intense, I soon after settled into a rhythm (especially during my hard playthrough). However, there was always a little pool of sweat underneath my wrists when I completed a play session.

By the end of your time with the game, if you stick with it, you'll find that you've become a lot better at playing and thinking about the game. For instance, you'll learn about how many shots it takes to put down each enemy with each gun, which enemies can be stun-locked with melee attacks and how to conserve ammo, how valuable it is to turn off lights, how dogs and bartenders are the nastiest enemies in the game (IMO - definitely have a shotgun when fighting dogs), and the tactic of just popping into view and then retreating to pick enemies off one by one. The tough thing is that pretty much all of this will be learned with trial and error. However, after dying you pop right back into the action almost instantaneously to try a new tactic, so this minimizes frustration. On some occasions, it's still quite irritating, such as the levels where backup is called after you finish killing enemies. On these occasions, you may wish that you'd turned out the lights on the first floor where enemies enter, or that you would've saved more ammo.

There are a few gripes I have with the game. First of all, and I probably missed this like an idiot, I didn't realize that you could get purchased weapons from your trunk. I bought a hammer and it was displayed on my little corkboard. I was like, "oh, that's it?" Maybe the Grim Reaper is a weapons collector? So maybe the game could be a bit more explicit about this?

Secondly, there was a level in "1000 Year Royals" (the second section) where you have to destroy four ash statues within a certain time limit. I was able to do it on the normal difficulty, but on hard it was virtually impossible. I created a route that I felt was extremely efficient, and died many many times without coming up with an alternative. On one occasion, I reached the door that the last statue was behind, but was gunned down with perhaps a second left on the clock. When the time runs out, you are killed instantly. However, at the time of this review, you can hide in the vent as time expires and then emerge to finish the level. I'm not sure if this was intended by the developer, but it was the only way I could beat the level. It's weird to have this time pressure when every other level in the game is best completed by using strategy and patience. Also, it makes the game a little less accessible to those without as much dexterity. I understand that not every game has to work for every person, but this particular level is an anomaly in the game.

Despite initially not making the best use of my purchased weapons and my troubles with the aforementioned level in hard mode, I had an exhilarating time with the game. If you had a fun time with Hotline Miami or Not a Hero, you'll absolutely find something to like here. With the exception of Hotline Miami's soundtrack, DEADBOLT is the superior game.

37722296.review:
Okay, I definitely didn't expect it when I first bought it, but this game took me for a ride. I was expecting it to be forgettable, and not a worthwhile purchase.

I was wrong.

This game combines some of my favorite aspects of storytelling: mysteriousness, things left for interpretation, dark themes, dark atmospheres but yet an overall soothing atmosphere. It turned the underworld into a city in which it's always night, and everyone has to leave eventually. The enemies represent different kinds of people: junkies who died of overdose, those betrayed by a lover and those driven to suicide. They are each represented by their counterparts: zombie junkies, lustful vampires and paramilitary skeleton gangsters. I love this classification of enemies and how they all have a background (some even offered by tapes in-game). It has a unique style, which I really like.

Gameplay-wise, like many may have already pointed out, this is like NOT A HERO combined with Hotline Miami. However, it shines in aspects that some of those lack. There is A LOT of cover that you can use to hide from certain enemies. There's some interesting mechanics i like as well, such as the use of sound and light to distract or attract enemies to you, depeding on how you want to take them out. There's weapon variety that can affect how you play, ranging from silenced pistols and shotguns, to a scythe that's risky but simpler to manneuver around. However, this game SHOULD NOT be taken lightly. Mistakes can be costly, and unlike NOT A HERO or Hotline Miami, the sometimes puzzle-like aspects of the gameplay can make some of Deadbolt's deaths frustrating, having you redoing levels after several minutes (or hours like in some of my experiences because I get too nervous and just sit there thinking for a while). If you get frustrated easily I can't recommend this for you. 

The music is AMAZING. Each gang has their own musacal themes they stick by, and they are all relaxing to listen to. Chris Christodoulou's work and it's usage does an incredible job at setting the atmosphere correctly for the levels. 

Deadbolt has a level editor. I've made some levels of my own, but because I'm a shy snowflake I can't bring myself to publish them. It's a good editor, but I wish it had a more explicit way of replicating some aspects or scenes from the main story, I just can't figure some of that on my own. It adds lots of replayability.

My only complaint here is that items that are too close to one another are sometimes tricky to interact around. For example, if there's a bed next to a light switch, you may end up turning the lights on and off instead of getting behind cover, leading to some unfair deaths.

I like this game, and I continue making levels for it and playing it constantly. Hopefully this review helps. I really want people to like this game, and can only hope the best for it.

Very good sidescroller, with a puzzle-like approach to level completion involving a good variety of weapons and tools available to help you clear levels. Soundtack is as good if not better than Hopoo's last game, Risk of Rain. Art style retains the simple charm of Risk of Rain, but differentiates itself enough to stand out as its own style. Mechanically, it is simple and robust, but has a great deal of interaction with different elements of the stage. For example, you can use your weapon to shoot out lights, distract enemies, or draw hordes to a trap. 

Plays similarly to Hotline Miami in terms of a puzzle approach to shooter with quick resets upon failure, with a heavier influence from Gunpoint(although much more grim and with not as much humor) in terms of level design and approach. 

Heavily underappreciated considering the quality of the game, as well as the notable improvement in general game design from the developers since their last game.

36907744.review:
I'm unsure where to begin, honestly. Let's start with the premise. You, the Reaper, are tasked by your mysterious employer with investigating the significance of a strange new drug, called Ash, which unravels into a conspiracy between three undead gangs: the Zombie Kingz, the 1000 Year Royals, and the Dredged.

This game is often described as a cross between Hotline Miami and Gunpoint, which does paint a decent picture of what to expect. The game has a side on perspective like Gunpoint, though the gameplay is a little more slow-paced than Hotline Miami. Not all enemies drop their weapons, meaning ammo conservation and aiming for headshots is key to completing a level, and while running in and playing on reaction time alone is possible, you die in one hit, so it's often better to plan out your assault.

The Reaper can turn into smoke with a flick of a lighter, allowing him to enter vents to flank enemies, and knocking on doors can lure them in for an easy kill. Enemies can also hear your gunfire depending on how loud your weapon is, and enemies react differently to this (generally, melee wielding enemies charge straight towards the noise, whereas gun-toting enemies usually take cover and wait for a few seconds before investigating). Flicking off lights limits their visibility.

This predictability allows you to plan how to tackle each room. Or alternatively, you can rush in and shoot everything. There are many weapons in the game, whether available to pick up within levels or buy from the gun dealer at the docks, there are weapons available for most playstyles. 

The game's soundtrack is excellent, too. If you've played Risk of Rain you're likely familiar with the game's composer, Chris Christodoulou. I've personally purchased the soundtrack off Bandcamp and listen to it regularly. 

With the game comes a level editor that allows you to make your own levels and share them on the workshop. There are many excellent maps available on the workshop, some even setting up their own narrative through cutscenes and unique tricks that the levels in the main game don't take advantage of.

Deadbolt is a game I've come to be obsessed with. I simply love it - from its atmosphere, its storytelling with hints littered throughout, the gameplay and the music, I can say it is one of my favourite games of all time. It's not without its faults - some deaths can feel unfair, particularly when enemies overlap with one another, hiding so you only see one of them, and sometimes enemies can behave unpredictably, but such faults, in my opinion, don't detract from my overall enjoyment of the game.

36624825.review:
[h1][b]Deadbolt[/b] - Ein waschechtes Killerspiel![/h1]

Es ist mitten in der Nacht. Im schwachen Schein einer Straßenlaterne stehen wir vor einem von Zombies besetzten Haus, Schalldämpfer-Pistole und Blendgranate im Anschlag. Durch die Kanalisation geht es ins Haus. Türe auf, Deckenlampe zerstören, zwei gezielte Schüsse und ab ins Untergeschoss. Flashbang werfen, Vorschlaghammer aufheben und die Untoten sind wieder dahingeschieden. "Area cleared, Killer out."

[b]Der Haken des Sensenmanns[/b]
So in etwa sieht jedenfalls der Idealverlauf aus, wenn man eine der knapp 30 Missionen im Spiel angeht. In der Praxis läuft es dann doch oft anders, was insbesondere daran liegt, dass unsere Spielfigur, der Sensenmann, nur ein Treffer aushält. Deadbolt ist ein knallhartes Spiel, für jeden Fehler wird man umgehend bestraft. Checkpoints gibt es nicht - wer den Löffel abgibt, muss die Mission bis auf wenige Ausnahmen also komplett neu starten. Das dabei trotzdem nur selten echter Frust aufkommt hat Deadbolt mehreren Faktoren zu verdanken. Zum Einen ist hier die übersichtliche Größe der Maps zu nennen: Beim Neustart sind wir sofort zurück in der Action und haben das Ziel unmittelbar vor Augen. Zudem sind die zweckmäßig gute Gegner-KI und die vielen verschiedenen Möglichkeiten zum Vorgehen in einem Level von großer Bedeutung. Letztendlich ist auch die große Auswahl an verschiedenen Nah- und Fernkampfwaffen zu erwähnen, von denen wir immer zwei mit in den Auftrag nehmen können. Klappt es mit einer Kombination nicht, versuchen wir es eben mit einem anderen Equipment.
Das Leveldesign variiert optisch leider nur marginal, spielerisch gehen die Entwickler von [i]Hopoo Games[/i] aber einen guten Weg. Gerade die vielfältigen und spielerisch großteils sehr gut ausgestalteten Gegnertypen sind wichtig, denn so müssen wir unseren Spielstil stetig etwas anpassen. Angefangen mit recht simpel aufgebauten Maps, müssen wir uns später gleich um zwei mehrstöckige Häuser zur selben Zeit kümmern. Mit unserem Sensenmann geraten wir so oft in extrem brenzlige Situationen, denen wir nur mit einer schnellen Auffassungsgabe entkommen. Das generelle Niveau der Level ist konstant hoch, nur das gewisse Etwas an denkwürdigen, überraschenden Momenten hat mir bis auf ein paar positive Ausnahmen gefehlt.
Obwohl des knalligen Schwierigkeitsgrades des Spiels, stimmt die Lernkurve. Neue Spielelemente und Gegner werden peu a peu eingeführt, sodass die Neuerungen nie überfordern aber immer für frische Vorgehensweisen sorgen. Mit durch Levelabschlüsse verdienten Credits können wir uns im Hub außerdem neue Waffen (ich empfehle die Sense!) kaufen. Ein motivierendes Fortschrittssystem, das für zusätzliche Abwechslung sorgt und außerdem den Wiederspielwert erhöht. Aber auch mit einem einmaligen Durchlauf aller Level ist der Nicht-Speedrun-Profi bereits um die 7 Stunden beschäftigt. 

[b]Das wummt rein![/b]
Zur Story habe ich bisher noch nichts gesagt und das hat auch einen Grund. Die steht nämlich so sehr im Hintergrund, dass man sie auch ohne weiteres nahezu komplett ignorieren könnte. Vor den jeweiligen Missionen bekommen wir in unserem gemütlichen Kaminzimmer ein kurzes Briefing von unserem geheimnisvollen Auftraggeber, den [i]Candles[/i]. Die Texte sind (auf englisch) stimmungsvoll geschrieben und geben den anschließenden Missionen einen roten Faden. Zudem können wir auf den Maps Kassetten mit Einblicken in das "Leben" unserer Gegner aufsammeln. Generell hat mich die von der griechischen Mythologie angehauchte Rahmenhandlung durchaus etwas neugierig gemacht, doch eine Storyoffenbarung sollte man nicht erwarten.
Optisch setzt das Spiel auf einen dunklen Pixel-Stil, dessen Umgebungen großteils aber recht detailarm und austauschbar wirken. Der Sensenmann selbst und sein vom Kaminfeuer erleuchteter Unterschlupf sind stilistisch fein designt, doch dieses Niveau können die Gegner und Level-Umgebungen bis auf wenige Ausnahmen leider nicht halten. Zumindest wirken die Animationen flüssig und glatt. Hinderlich wird die eher grobe Pixel-Grafik auch, wenn sich viele Interaktionsmöglichkeiten nah beieinander befinden. Wenn wir eigentlich nur eine Tür schließen wollen aber ständig den sich nebenan befindenen Lichtschalter betätigen (beide Aktionen liegen auf der gleichen Taste), kann sich das in der Hitze des Gefechts durchaus mal zu einem vermeidbaren Problemchen entwickeln. Abgesehen von diesem Schnitzer funktioniert die Steuerung nach etwas Eingewöhnung aber relativ gut.
Das Deadbolt trotz des eher kargen Äußeren ein sehr atmosphärisches und intensives Spiel ist, hat es zu großen Teilen auch seinem hervorragenden Soundtrack zu verdanken, dessen Komponist auch schon für den tollen OST von [i]Risk of Rain[/i] verantwortlich gezeichnet hat. Obwohl die Vielfalt der Musikstücke gar nicht mal so groß ist, sorgen die exzellente Abmischung und der dynamische Einsatz für echte Killer-Stimmung.

FAZIT
[h1]Deadbolt ist ein Geheimtipp für Fans von knallharten und schnellen Stealth-Shootern! Das optisch austauschbare Mapdesign und die wenigen Steuerungsschnitzer lassen sich bei der enorm intensiven Atmosphäre verzeihen.[/h1]

WERTUNG

36616948.review:
I have had so much fun playing this game. It is extremely unique, and as a person who is rather into pixel graphics, this is a number one for me. It features mechanics which allow you to get an edge over your enemies, who are statistically much more powerful than you, as if you get shot once, it is game over. This game is oft times challenging, and very rewarding; and yes, there is a hard difficulty for this game which is thrice as rewarding. 

Improvisation is not an option. This game requires a lot of trial and error, and planning ahead. Mechanics such as turning out the lights, setting off alarms, or knocking on doors will disorientate your enemies, and allow you to take them on alone. The only frustration for me is that lots of different actions with different objects use the same key, and when they overlap they can sometimes literally get you stuck in a room. Albeit rare, this is pretty annoying sometimes, but is not an immediate problem by any means. Enough said, this game deserves a 9/10.

Absolutely unfun to play.  Enemies quickly become bullet sponges to most weapons you can bring into a stage, the cover system doesn't really work since cover is nowhere near most places you want to use it, enemies aren't predictable, and YOU DIE IN ONE HIT.  It turns into an enforced-stealth game where stealth is extremely unreliable since the enemies aren't predictable and (aside from zombies) never calm down.

Heck, stealth doesn't even help you that much.  Only zombies seem to care about headshots, so the sledgehammer is the only weapon that guarantees a silent kill (and you can't bring that into a stage).  The only reason to avoid making noise is so that enemies don't all go on alert and swarm you.

35985566.review:
Visually and aurally, it's lovely. As to how it plays...it's a mixed bag.

I find the control scheme clunky and awkward. With any gun equipped, you have to hold RMB to actually use the gun, aim with the mouse, then click LMB to fire. I suspect this is a kludge to work around the 2-weapon carry limit without having to have your fist always available as a weapon (why it couldn't instead be an always-equipped 3rd weapon would require input from the devs, I guess). I also found it weird that, while the "up" key in the WASD layout is used to go both up and downstairs, it's not used to go into or out of vents, which instead defaults to "E" (not the worst choice, but less useful than Space since it requires moving from one of your movement keys to begin with - galling since S in the WASD layout isn't used here, for whatever reason). Given that you don't get a lot of time  to react to what's happening in the game, I find this a problem. It feels like there's a better control scheme for this game, and I think it's probably controller-based. Given the game is a year and a half old, though, I doubt that's forthcoming. 

Coupled with a "no checkpoints" system that means you play each level from scratch every time, this means that a level that starts out as a challenge moves from challenging to tedious - because you'll have worked out how to get through half of it, get killed in the second half and have to start over again. Which on a small level is ok, but on a larger level gets dull.

It's a pity, because when the controls aren't getting in the way and the level design is balanced right, it's a lot of (tough-as-nails) fun and a lot of effort has gone into the presentation. But the controls cause snarls and levels are wobbly a bit too often for me to enjoy it consistently, especially when compared to how smoothly games like HM or NAH flow by comparison.

35903693.review: This is a great game, one of my favorites. I love the style, the controls, the mechanics; everything just works so well. The sountrack is absolutely phenomenal, every song works so perfectly in the levels they are in. This has to be one of the best development teams I have ever seen, which is surprising for how small they are. The catch though is that this game is insanely difficult, but that is part of what makes it so great. I don't know how many times I've died in this game and just thoght "one more try". If you want to beat this game you have to plan everything, have perfect timing, fast reflexes, and be aware of everything happening around you. One of my favorite aspects of this game is that you have the decision to go in guns ablazing, sneak around and be a complete ghost, or do something in between. Both play styles present their own advantages and disadvantages. The offensive approach allows for quicker level completion but you also have a better chance of being ganged up on. The stealth approach gives you more control over what happens in the level but comes with the challenge of not being detected. I'm not going to recommend this to everyone because its not everyone's type of game, but for anyone who likes this kind of game definitely pick this up.

35562446.review:
If you're looking for a hybrid between Gunpoint and Hotline Miami, this game delivers.  The game is difficult, but not unfairly so.  Like Hotline Miami, you will die constantly trying to find the right pattern.  One shot kills most enemies, but one bullet kills you, too.  There's a nice variety of weapons, level types, and secrets.

Why this is good for achievement hunters:
(I like these types of games a lot and will therefore be biased)

- Nice pixel graphics that makes you enjoy the environment. The style of the game is interesting too.
- Controls are perfect. They do as they're told and you most certainly do not die due to bad control. Not at all.
- Very short loading if any at all. If you die or screw up you can retry in a matter of miliseconds. No waiting around.
- Some achievements are easy and gets you hooked while some are reserved for the veterans or bold.
- Difficulty is not TOO insane. It is hard at a fun level and does not feels like you have to be asian to complete.

You go out on missions where you have to complete certain tasks, which most likely is to kill someone. Enemies react to sounds so you have to decide if you want to go silent assassin or just bust in and wish for the best. The enemies also start to vary very early in the game so you will have to use different tactics at some points. The environment supplies you with cover, lights and possible weapons to be used such as pistols or kitchen knives.

After each mission you are allowed to relax and brief on the next mission in you apartment. Here it is also possible to overview achievements, visit the nearby docks, retry earlier missions or simply continue with the next mission. If you decide to visit the docks you are able to purchase new weapons in exchange for the souls that you collect during mission, or by completing achievements.

Very fun game!

35281184.review:
Being a fan of the old assassin-related games (Hitman, Thief, Hotline Miami) and Stealth Games (Metal Gear, Splinter Cell), I can say that Deadbolt delivers what it promises. Not without flaws, but the fun surpasses any problems that bounced into the way.

The story is simple and straightforward, but allows for many plot twists to appear... for those who pay attention to details. You're Reaper, tasked by the fire into delivering a swift death to those who sway astray in a city filled with all manners of undead. You can carry two weapons at a time, and for souls that you gain through completing missions and earning achievements, you buy special weapons that you can carry with you. 2D, it enables the player to use air ducts, sewer holes and toilets to sneak upon unsuspecting foes, or, if you prefer the John Woo style, to hide behind objects and use them as shields as you deliver headshots.

The main key for a good stealth/assassination game is adaptability, allowing a player to approach the same problem from different angles yet offering different challenges, and for most of the missions, Deadbolt allows you to do so without getting easy, for example, If you try to sneak, be aware that there is a delay between entering and leaving air ducts, leaving you wide open to be killed (in this game, one hit = death) and if you go guns blazing, ammo is rather scarce.

The soundtrack is really, really good, following you (as long you're indoors) as you fight through zombies in shantytown houses and nightclubs, a shame it's not being sold or can be found alongside the game, as far as I know.

There are some problems, though. Some bugs can be found here and there, and if you drop your weapon close to a ventilation shaft or a door, prepare for a world of pain and possible death since there is nearly always only a single command, regardless of how many acceptable subjects are available, as in, try to close a door while being chased by enemies, and you'll end up just swapping weapons, and so forth.

This complaint will be more due personal taste, but the story could have been more clearer and more plentiful, the same 'fault' that befalls Risk of Rain. The game ends with many questions that won't be answered so soon...

Regardless of these shortcomings, I do believe that the game was worth what I paid for, and more.

35121517.review:
[h1]玩法[/h1]
一款优秀的2D像素风潜入游戏，很好地平衡了潜入和暴力元素，该怂的时候不能急躁，该干的时候不能犹豫。除了操作，游戏对资源管理和路线规划也有一定的要求，弹药是有限的，用什么枪打什么敌人，先打哪边的敌人才能在弹药耗尽之前拿到下一把枪，都需要在一次次失败中调整。由于关卡配置是固定的，游戏对手残玩家还算友好，靠着反复重玩形成的肌肉记忆和一点运气，手残党也可能拿到全五星评分。

[h1]手感[/h1]
游戏手感流畅，打击感不错。枪支种类丰富，各有特色，近战武器却只有4种，仅起到补充作用，想体验花式虐杀只能出门左转去迈阿密了。不过大镰刀刷刷的收割声还是让我欲罢不能，此外本作还有非常爽快猎奇的马桶杀不容错过。

[h1]画面[/h1]
画面是很精细的像素，各种人物造型和动作表现力十足。遗憾的是，场景则略显单调。很多房间只有寥寥几件家具，背景墙也是单一的色块，显得空空荡荡。

[h1]音乐[/h1]
本作的原声音乐是一大亮点，码头的凄冷萧瑟，吸血鬼酒吧的躁动迷幻，主角公寓的慵懒温暖，都被音乐渲染得淋漓尽致。这么好的原声他们竟然不卖soundtrack？

[h1]剧情[/h1]
剧情基本靠文字撑，连个过场动画都没有，文字量也不大，但是文笔意外地好。通过关卡衔接时的短短几行文字，和怪物掉落的类似日记的文本，游戏建立起一个颇有新意的世界观，讲述了一个不落俗套的故事，并相当细腻地展现了形形色色的不死族内心的欲望、彷徨、恐惧和疲惫。更难得的是，文字并不晦涩，能把平实的语言用的好，才是真正的好作者。

[h1]总评：8/10，优秀的小品级潜入游戏。[/h1]

34946092.review:
I'm honestly not sure whether to recommend Deadbolt or not, so let's line things up and have a look at what we've got.

Firstly, the presentation is AAA. Graphics, music, sound design, writing, all of it, pretty much 10/10 in every single case. The only exceptions are one or two levels where flashing lights and similar obscure what's actually going on which is... again, not optimal.

Secondly, the controls are largely smooth, simple and easy to handle(on some occasions, however, when two interactables are very close to each other, the game can get confused and that can get you killed). By and large if you come out at the bottom of a situation, it was because you hestitated or planned poorly.

Third, though... we've got the level design, which is where things come apart a bit. Despite the game's insistence that there are multiple ways to deal with the various levels, it honestly doesn't feel that way. Rather, a few levels have multiple approaches, but most of them feel like they have one optimal approach, and if you manage to win while deviating from that, it's because you got lucky or exploited AI flaws.

Sometimes it's okay, though, because the optimal approach is easy enough to spot, and it's a matter of figuring out the execution. But in a few cases it's like playing a Roberta Williams adventure game where you're trying to figure out the moon logic that the devs employed.

It's also particularly aggravating in situations where the first 50% of a level is easy caketown that you end up redoing over and over because there's one really miserable difficulty bump right at the mid point.

Ultimately what makes me verge on giving this a recommendation rather than not, is the price. If it had cost ANY more, it would've been a clear no. Really feels like the game needed a few more cycles of testing and opinions from testers before release.

34945302.review:
Phenominal! DEADBOLT is an action game about reaping the undead with a variety of weapons, I almost think of it as a puzzle game at it's core. Don't get me wrong, DEADBOLT requires plenty of reflexes and a quick trigger finger, but each stage can be thought of as a chessboard and the enemies, opposing pieces. Which pieces you take first and how you take them is key to winning. 

A number of zombies, vampires, hellhounds, and other creatures populate the rooms that make up every stage. They respond to gunfire and other noises, as well as light level. Since you die in one hit and enemies, while slow to react, can be very accurate, it's wise to plan your approach. These little murder puzzles are pretty addictive and the excellent soundtrack and crisp pixel art really add to DEADBOLT's charm. 

Overall, if you enjoy challenging, tactical action, you should consider giving this game a try!

34850697.review:
Стоит начать с того, что я совершенно не поклонник жанра Стелс и за весь свой игровой опыт играл в какого-нибудь Хитмэна и на кортах ползал в играх от беседки. В первую очередь я заинтересовался DEADBOLT из-за разработчиков игры, эти ребята уже сделали прекрасный и уникальный рогалик Risk of Rain, который до сих пор манит своей атмосферой и геймплеем. DEADBOLT - это не игра про отсиживание в углах и нудное выжидание, это чертов экшен, который не дает расслабиться. Банально, но вполне правильно сравнивать игру с Hotline Miami, бодрый геймплей с постоянными ваншотами главного героя и врагов. Игра прокачивается вместе с вами, поэтому со временем появляется множество новых механик, пушек и врагов, каждый последующий уровень все еще удивляет. Великолепный арсенал действительно разного оружия для разных врагов и ситуаций. Восхитительный атмосферный саундтрек, который хочется переслушивать отдельно от игры снова и снова. Да сюда даже реиграбельность завезли: хард мод, пользовательские карты, различные достижения для безумцев, но ведь дело совершенно не в этом, проходить и перепроходить DEADBOLT хочется, потому что игра сделана с душой и заставляет наслаждаться каждой минутой проведенной в ней. 

Определенно одна из лучших инди, что довелось пройти.
Четыре раза пройти.

34278051.review:
After having played Deadbolt for a few hours (plus some extra when it was still in beta), I have this to say: This game is very much worth your time, and your money.
The entire feel of the game, from its fast-paced glass cannon gameplay to its soundtrack, reminded me very distinctly of Hotline Miami. However, unlike Jacket (who's amongst the land of the living), you're a 'reaper', a mysterious being assigned with the job of dragging runaway souls back to the underworld. Due to your supernatural origins, you gain a rather interesting ability to turn into smoke, thus allowing you to quickly zip through accessable vents and even sewage pipes. Yes, you read that right: Sewage Pipes. What this means is that you can sneak into buildings by entering a manhole, and then appearing out of the sh**ter. However, if there are any enemies currently using the sh**ter, you have the terrifying and mildly humourous ability to appear regardless, causing their bodies to explode violently. Whether or not this would result in the player character getting sh** on his skull is never really made clear. However, there are also other not so supernatural things you can pull off to give yourself an advantage, such as shooting out the lights to confuse your enemies/prey, or knocking on doors to attract enemies, either to kill them or to distract them so that you can attack someone else.
The enemies and NPCs you face (or at least the ones I've faced within my uncompleted playthrough) are taken from all over; a talking fire, demons, vampires, zombies, and even the ferryman of the greek afterlife, Charon.  Charon acts as a storefront for you to spend the games currency of souls; souls are earned after you complete a mission, and depending on how well you did it, you'll either get lots of souls, or barely any. These souls will then be given to charon, who will in turn give you weapons; the better the weapon, the more souls you must bring him. The final key NPC is a fire, who will speak to you each time you sit down within your house; this fire will be what gives you missions, as well as small facts and tips about the game's enemies. You can also collect tapes from certain dead enemies, which will then unlock some filler text which you can read later. However, I didn't manage to collect that many in my playthrough, so I can't say how well they do the job of acting as story filler. I think their main purpose is merely to act as some more guff for completionists.

All in all, this game is a blast, and really tickles my love of the supernatural in all the right places (no homo).
10/10

34093554.review:
DEADBOLT is a game that rewards cunning players with a good sense of tactics, a quick reaction time, and sometimes even stealthy maneuvering. It is a game that is equal parts careful planning and smooth execution. There are multiple solutions to every problem, and each level is crafted in a unique manner that allows for differing attack patterns. Knocking on doors or turning on radios for distractions, turning off or shooting out lights to decrease enemy visibility, and flipping over tables and opening refrigerator doors for cover are all par for the course. Story elements are cleverly introduced during specific missions, and at every briefing which takes place in the comfort of your own home. Walking out of your house will take you to the Docks, where you can buy guns in exchange for souls that are earned by completing missions.

However, there is one stipulation: its difficulty. Take one hit and you die, with very few exceptions. And die you will, many times, before coming up with a combination of actions that yields a victory. That is, in itself, the biggest satisfaction you'll get from DEADBOLT; as fun as it is to kill your targets, move through the vents, and mow down skeletons with the Old World Rifle, the best feeling you get will be from beating the level that you were stuck on for hours. DEADBOLT is very hard, but it's also very fun.

That being said, it took me more than a few sessions to push through this somewhat short, but very rewarding game. It's probably the most fun I've ever had with an indie platformer. DEADBOLT feels similar to Gunpoint, but much darker and more violent, which is why I like it better. The art style is very good quality for pixel art, reminiscent of games like Risk of Rain. The animations are beautifully crafted and the diegetic music is amazing. My only issue with DEADBOLT is how short it was; I would have loved a few more levels, or even DLC for it. Even a digital soundtrack would have been great too. Still, I think this is a must-have for fans of the Stealth-Action Platformer genre.

9/10, am playing it again, this time on hard mode. Very fun game, I highly recommend it.

34073626.review: Hopoo Games have done it again. DEADBOLT is very different from their last game, Risk of Rain. The game is like a giant puzzle with some levels having a ridiculous amount of paths you can take to win. The story and atmosphere is surprisingly good for what seems like another stealth platformer (even though Deadbolt isn't a platformer like, say, Gunpoint). The soundtrack, composed by Chris Christadoulou (again just like Risk of Rain) is fucking amazing, especially the song for your home base and the final level's music which could encite an emotional reaction you may not have expected you could have. The only real issues I can think of are how enemy behavior can be inconsistent in a few situations, with different enemies getting alerted by the same sound with only slightly different positioning on your part, as well as Hard Mode being completely unfun that mostly involves running out of ammo and killing yourself, and the Death and Famine achievements, which need to be gained on the same save file before you can even think about getting 100% and which require no deaths AND beating the game in one hour, which I think is too high of a bar for someone who wants to just start working towards completion. Other than that combat is amazing, there are a lot of different options at different times, the boss fights are actually interesting AND in a stealth game at the same time, the art is beautiful, the music is even better, etc etc. I could go on for a while about how much this game does right. A relatively short game that you'll love, if you're anything like me and enjoy a good challenge.

34029636.review:
People compare this game to Hotline Miami and Gunpoint. There's a good reason for that. Deadbolt's combat is akin to Hotline Miami's, but as a side-scroller rather than top-down, and you do some stealthing through buildings going in doors and changing floors, turning lights on/off, etc., like in Gunpoint. I really liked both of those games.

However, the one thing those two games had that Deadbolt does [i]not[/i] have are checkpoints of some sort. In Hotline Miami, if you completed a floor of a building and took the stairs to the next floor, which was still the same mission, then you died, you got to start the floor over, instead of having to start the entire level over. Gunpoint is even more generous. Without checkpoints, a die-in-one-hit game can be very frustrating. 

I put up with replaying the same levels again and again until I completed the first big "chapter" which consisted of nine missions, and decided that was enough for me. The music was great, the visuals were alright, though the storytelling was a bit whimical with no real characters or dialog between characters. If you care about narrative, dialog, and characters, Deadbolt is devoid of these things, at least in its first handful of hours. If it picks up, it's too little too late to get my interest. Deadbolt makes me want to play Hotline Miami or Gunpoint again, if only because it feels to me like a less fun version of both of those games mashed together. I do recommend those two games, though. They can be challenging but their checkpointing systems are legit.

33688435.review:
Deadbolt is a really neat and interesting game. It's not entirely unique by its own merits, but it has a charm all of its own. It plays in a similar fashion to Gunpoint, but without the hacking aspect. It also plays rather similarly to Hotline Miami in that combat can sometimes require multiple, rapid acts of precision. Also that it frequently requires trial and error. 

Weaponry and the methods used to complete a mission are all very satisfying. While the game advertises the ability to choose your way to accomplish missions, this is a bit of a white lie. Technically you [i]can[/i] pick and choose your path through most missions. However, the objective is usually in an area with only 1 entrance. And speaking of objectives, missions will have 1 of 2 (sometimes both!) objectives: "Use this/these object(s)" and "Kill X enemies."

The game is simple and straightforward. You play a level and then you are taken back to your apartment to get briefed on the next level. In between levels you have the chance to buy new weapons or read some lore items. While I enjoy having bite-sized portions of game to play, I do really wish that there was a "bigger picture" for the story. The disconnected presentation of the world and its events really detracts from the storyline being presented here, even if the game does require that you read between the lines a little. 

Once you're in a mission, you find yourself standing next to your really classy car. From there you set upon your grisly work. A really neat piece of flavor is that your weapon selection is conveniently in the trunk of your car. Prior to engaging the mission you get the option to swap out some weapons. Once you're done, Reaper closes the trunk and sets the alarm on the car again. The game has a huge amount of charm hiding in its sharply down pixel graphics which I think sets it apart from similar games in this genre.

Sound quality is superb. Your weapons all sound lethal and satisfying to use. The controls are tights and responsive. The game is difficult in a way that requires a little patience, a little skill and good reaction speed. The game is tough at times but never feels unfair, and is usually the result of your own failings. Also, the game is really swell in that it will occasionally pop up hints after you've died a handful of times.

Deadbolt was a neat game that kept me entertained the whole way through. It offers a unique enough experience to stand out, even if it could have sorely used a little more actual meat on its bones. The soundtrack is definitely worth a listen, as well.

33575632.review:
If any single track could describe the rhythm gameplay through sound, Blood on the Dancefloor is the beat of DEADBOLT, a stealth-action hitman game in the style of Hotline Miami. An experience that prefers to dwell in the shadows, contemplating the next ambush, slowly rising out of the stillness of a gasp before the matter becomes a chaotic scramble with only the dead-beating pulse of the Reaper left alone in silence. Then hitting the elevator button with a smoke-break to take off the nerves before continuing the job. 

This is the soul of DEADBOLT that makes the distress of failure and improvising solutions in advance a fleeting concern from another contract that you don’t know why you accepted it other than the habit at showing up to parties when everyone is dead.  

[h1]Hotline Underworld: 00-DEATH[/h1]

Although the two experiences are very similar, DEADBOLT and HM cater to different tastes. Whereas the HM series imitate snuff films, the psychedelic disillusion of reality, and of entertainment that glorifies its violence as much as examines its lasting effects, DEADBOLT offers a film noir underworld ruled by a crime syndicate within its purgatory of the undead with an even greater lack of purpose behind the Reaper’s motives. It is from the presentations as well as in the core gameplay that show DEADBOLT is perhaps the more “Hitman” approach, rewarding usage of opportunities and inventiveness rather than twitchiness of HM. 

As a game and as a story, DEADBOLT chooses its style and simplicity over being convoluted, choosing to revel in the methodology of a hit-and-run. This is indicative through the small gameplay refinements from the delays between raising their weapons between the alert phases; from the player’s own delay in aiming their weapon; from the versatility of tools, environmental distractions and alternative routes within each level; and the missions never being as simple as they initially appear when the situation is compromised. It is also apparent through the narrative that focuses on Death as a contract-killer sent to disenfranchise the infrastructure of zombie gangs upon vampire mafias upon skeleton mercenaries seeking to dominate the land of the living. Neither the gameplay nor the story become any more complicated than the deceptively puzzle-like contracts.  

Instead of adding more elements to the gameplay or adding more depth to motives and backstory, the storyline prefers to use poetic fragments of details from your victims in an already undead world. The city is referred to as the Place, the main character as The Reaper and the Reaper’s contractor as the Fire, Details of the plot remain vague with little to no dialogue to the point where the game feels like the style was done for the sake of its art rather than for a purpose. As a result, the game’s greatest value is its consistent pace of challenge and variety, something missing from the HM games that shifted its focus from allowing various playstyles into reflex challenges and where DEADBOLT rewards the more perceptive players who know their enemies and tools greater than themselves.

[h1]Clubbing At the Monster Mash[/h1] 

Although what I truly love about DEADBOLT that sets it apart from other stealth-action hybrid games is the enemies can be more creative as a result of having supernatural enemies. One type of zombies can use their severed heads as a spotter while their body is detached; some vampires can have phylacteries that prevent them from truly dying the first time; one type of skeleton is able to cast magic that can make them vanish as well as revive fallen allies. Even the variants for these categories differentiate their weaponry and toughness, which offers a surprising amount of variety to a game that couldn’t be possible in more grounded worlds.

The structure of the game, as previously mentioned, is a three-act progression of hits on three levels of corruption within the Place: The Zombies, The Vampires and the Skeletons. Only the first Act is limited in using one category of enemies, which never feels tiring because the threats are diverse. The other two acts begin with introducing new enemies before combining them with the previous variety to not only benefit the overall challenge of the game but also the narrative of disrupting the power-play from the bottom-up. Rewards come in the form of ratings on the success of the job, which earns you more souls only earned by completing achievements to unlock more tools for the Reaper, and the additional content provided by the level-editor as well as the hard mode that reworks the original twenty-seven levels truly explores the limits of its appeal.

Perhaps the one example of a level that never seizes its idea for future levels on being inventive is The Tinkerer. Instead of another target amongst a crowd of other hostiles, The Tinkerer is a challenge of navigating the death-traps to eliminate the security personnel of a crazed technician trapped within his home knowing the Reaper is coming for him. The ending is simple irony of triggering the technician’s own defenses against him without the satisfaction of taking the Reaper. It’s this kind of playfulness with the level-design and environment that shines the player-freedom of its greater levels that the game never seems to capitalize on as much as the Hitman games.

[h1]One Button to Doom Them All[/h1]

If Volume was only guilty of creating a simplified Metal Gear game that would benefit from adding more player-agency to its mechanics, then DEADBOLT is guilty of not creating more of these Hitman level deigns of poetic irony and playfulness within environments to enhance the core gameplay. The spirit captures the essence of HITMAN but not the replayability and mastery from playing with its mechanics. It’s perhaps easier to design for this goal in mind with a 3D environment rather than a 2D design; however, there are many mechanics like the ventilation systems, sound positioning, and distractions that are more tied to individual levels for one opportunity than across all of them.

One notable oversight in the game’s controls is the interact button. It is responsible for picking-up weapons, interacting with distractions, turning off/on lights, opening and closing doors, crouching, entering and leaving vents—it simply is doing too much for one button. This wouldn’t be as bad as it’s implemented where the mouse does not affect the context of that action, rather it’s the proximity with the player. This one button could literally be the death of you simply because your character picked-up a hammer when you meant to hide behind a couch. It’s strange that the game doesn’t map the cover-button to R as reloading weapons is not a mechanic whereas the game does set knocking to a separate button exclusively for knocking on doors. It makes no sense why the control-scheme was designed the way it is. 

More importantly, however, the limitation of one interactable button prevents the game from capitalizing on using it more often for traps, distractions and escapes more often in levels because the levels designed here mostly account for this problem. Had the developers tweaked the control-scheme, the open-nature of its game would have most likely pushed the game to the next level in earning its caliber as an unofficial Hitman experience. 

[h1]Reap What You Have Sown[/h1]

While shy of a new standard for stealth-action games, DEADBOLT manages to communicate the hunter and the hunted tension behind its exuberant style and refined simplicity of its gameplay. In the Place where only one soul can feel the fleeting fires of the Flame, the quiet mutterings of reflection simmer into nothing.  

“Thus the living, lone and sobbing, In the throes of anguish throbbing, With the loathsome Furies robbing, Night and noon of peace and rest. But beyond the groans and grating Of abhorrent Life, is waiting, Sweet Oblivion, culminating All the years of fruitless quest.”—H.P. Lovecraft, “Despair.”

33539404.review:
I've loved stealth games and one hit kill tactical shooters for as long as I can remember. Hotline Miami 1 and 2 ended up getting a couple thousand hours of gameplay from me back when I tried them on PS3 and 4 a few years back. DEADBOLT is one of the greatest games I've ever played, ranking up there with Hotline Miami, Snake Eater, Spelunky, Super Meat Boy, Ocarina of Time, etc, etc.
     The graphics are minimalistic but even if you don't like pixel art you should be able to appreciate the whole 'detailed but not really' aesthetic that lends itself well to the horror theme. Guns light up rooms and shoot out bulbs in fantastic intricacy as their pixel-y glass bits shatter and fall to the floor. Certain animations, such as knocking on doors or punching, become quickly endearing and memorable, much like Mario's jump or MegaMan's firing stance.
     Gameplay. It's like if Not A Hero decided to slow itself down and try to model itself after Rainbow Six 3: Raven Shield. You can only carry two weapons, and melee weapons can be thrown. Enemies have interesting interactions with the environment and your actions; For example, if you fired a few bullets into a room to clear it but someone else was wary, but not so wary they felt the need to check, they would end up pointing a gun at the door. If you knocked on the door two, three times in a normal rhythm, they will slowly lower their weapon and answer Death. If you knock frantically, they catch on to your jig and open the door and pop you.
     Music of this game is so good that my girlfriend who has never played it bought it on vinyl and plays it on loop. I listen to it about the same.

Please buy this and support quality developers! This is better than most AAA games I've bought for x3, x4, x5 the price.

33492374.review:
[h1]For the sake of brevity..[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Genre tags:[/b] Action, 2D, Stealth, Difficult, Pixel Art
[*][b]Value Proposition:[/b] It's relatively short but very challenging, there are also user levels. 
[*][b]BSERC[/b] - (Borderline Sardonic and Extremely Reductive Comparison): Gunpoint without Crosslink, Ronin without turns, a little bit “The Final Station”, a little bit “Not a Hero”
[/list]
[h1]Concomitant Exposition and Summation[/h1]

[b]DEADBOLT[/b] is not necessarily a unique game. But it's different enough to stand out. You play as the Reaper and must kill the dead – put them to proper rest.

You earn souls to be spent as currency to purchase and bring bigger and better weapons into the field. You can only hold 2 weapons at a time and you cannot reload. So, whatever is in the magazine or even just the chamber for some weapons, that's all the bullets you're going to get. So takes your shots quick and precisely. Additionally, everything can kill you in one hit so it's best to act fast, take cover and turn the lights down, maybe set up an ambush through distraction. 

Other than your keen senses and accuracy, the only other thing you'll have to keep you alive is stealth -- turning lights off, knocking on doors for distraction and of course your innate ability to turn into smoke and traverse though the air ducts. 

[i][b]THE GIST
Short, but very challenging game. It's very tense. I had to play it in short bursts because it quite honestly stressed me out. But that's neither here nor there. It's a very enjoyable game.[/b][/i]

33334464.review:
刚通完普通难度，来写写感受。
很早就听人推荐了游戏，在某太阳骑士演示过以后果断加入了愿望单，这次夏促就正好买下了。
游戏流程一共30关（？），作为独立游戏来说已经不短了，特别是个别一些关卡需要好好规划一下路线。相比较于同类游戏迈阿密热线，考研脑力比考研操作更多。
操作手感除了武器叠在门上或者通风管道上时蛋疼以外，其他时候非常顺畅，射击感特别是爆头做得不错。各种武器各有特点，就是魂给的太少了，而且能买到的武器种类也不多。不过实话说一杆枪不买也能顺利通关，丝毫不影响（千万别攒钱买死神镰刀）。
游戏风格偏黑暗，不像迈阿密热线那样慵懒迷幻。游戏剧情上主线没怎么搞懂，特别是最后一章以及最后两关，大概是没怎么品读炉火吟的小诗的锅。
总之，这个游戏值得购买。

Level-based stealth/action hybrid with a wide variety of weapons and mechanics. 
+ Tight controls
+ Excellent difficulty scaling
+ Fun and challenging achievements
+ A surprisingly interesting story
+ Jammin music
- Some keys run double duty

By the way: if you liked Hotline Miami you'll probably enjoy Deadbolt as well.

Note: When I launched the game I experienced a bug where all the sounds played but the screen stayed black. To fix it, I went into options.ini and changed AlternateSyncMethod from 0 to 1. Game worked fine afterwards.

So, now I've played through Deadbolt normal and hard mode.

It is an amazing game. I highly suggest you play it, if you are a fan of 2D shooters. You die in one hit and ammo is very rare. You've to outsmart your enemies, aim accurate and quick. It is a true challenge and great if you want to test your reflexes and just try to generally have a great time. Apart from normal and hard mode, which each took me roughly 4-5 hours (so 10 hours of fun total), one can also download custom maps. I'm about to check them out!

33260161.review:
Скажу честно, мне очень нравятся атмосферные игры. И именно этим эта игра и цепляет нас с самого начала. Ночные вылазки, грязные и обшарпаные дома, в стилизованной пиксельной графике, музыка и всё прочее. Однако, зацепить-то зацепила, а что с геймплеем, с сюжетом? "Чем игра может нас удержать?" - спросите вы. Ну... Есть тут пара проблем...

Итак, если вы читаете это, то уже 100 свечек из ста вам приглянулся графоний (кто не любит пиксели сразу же пропустят эту игру), а значит мы пропустим данный пункт.
Геймплей здесь довольно... специфичен. Да, благодаря тому, что это платформер, стрелять по врагам удобно, но как и во всеми любимом Hotline Miami, вы всё равно умудритесь выстрелить пару раз в стенку, целясь чуть ли не вплотную во врага. Ходит Жнец медленнее, чем тот же Джакет, а умирает так же, с одной пули/удара. А вот враги не такие тонкие и порой 4-6 выстрела в толстое тело вполне нормальное явление. Если, конечно, успеешь, так как перед выстрелом есть около 2-2.5 секунды, чтобы прибить супостата. И кажется, что это довольно много и можно словно Рембо бегать по уровню и разносить смерть, но... Не тут-то было. Сама игра заставляет нас думать и выжидать, постукивать в двери для привлечения внимания одного из группы, прятаться в вентеляционных шахтах, канализации и так далее. В игре проработан стелс и это отличает игру от HM во много раз и в положительную сторону.
Очень печалит отсутствие русского языка, так как сюжет здесь подаётся благодаря касетам с записями, падающих с врагов, а так же во время брифингов, во время которых Жнец общается со своим боссом. И возможно, он даже хорош, но Я не знаю английский... 
И ещё одна проблема, которая так же вытекает из-за отсутствия знаний иностранного - после покупки оружия у Харона его можно использовать, однако для этого нужно подойти в начале миссии к своему транспртному средству и, если ты никого ещё не убил, то взять купленное оружие. Я это узнал только к концу игры, а потому почти всю её прошёл со слабым начальным пистолетом, эх...

P.s. час игры Я абсолютно ничего не делал. Просто посадил Жнеца на кресло перед камином и сел слушать играющую в игре музыку. Thank for the new ambient music in my track listing, Hopoo Games.

33233044.review:
首先这款游戏整体玩法的方向为策略与潜入，加入了部分刺激爽快的战斗，在游戏过程中需要不停的尝试多种可以完成任务的方法，尽管这时候你已经死亡了N次。
优点：
->多种武器选择（包括远程和近战）
->BGM很赞，它的设定会根据进入的房间来触发
->潜入方式很有趣，好好利用通风管道击杀更多敌人
->游戏具有一定程度的挑战性，千万不要急躁
->美术效果不错，敌人死亡的物理碰撞让尸体碎片在墙上各种弹弹弹

缺点：
->直到游戏后期才会遇到陷阱以及特殊怪物
->敌人布局没有随机性，每次触发敌人路径几乎一样
->本体游戏章节较少

另外游戏还包含以下几个设定（仅推荐对此感兴趣的玩家）
->每把武器发出的声音大小是不一样的
->房间内的灯光会加长敌人的视野
->所有可以用“E”键遮挡的物件都可以抵御敌人的子弹（除近战敌人）
->主角可以利用通风管道随意进出，并且还可以在特定环境下秒杀敌人
->利用敲门声、微波炉的声音可以吸引敌人

评价
基本上游戏素质还算不错，开发者大概综合了部分横版动作游戏的精髓，并且在类型上做出了详细的定位，将潜入为主，简单粗暴的战斗为辅，血肉模糊视觉享受作为铺垫，使得游戏模式不再单一，能更多尝试不同的通关方法，刚开始总是想着无脑前冲见谁杀谁，之后发现就算是枪枪爆头也会存在子弹不够用的情况，而且通常在敌人多的环境下死亡几率非常高，于是慢慢对游戏开始有一种潜入的想法在里面了，每一步都小心翼翼的计划，通过声音引来敌人，或又故意让敌人发现，然后靠在门边用近战武器秒之（需要算好时间）来节省弹药，甚至可以进入通风管道一击必杀正在上厕所的敌人，当你弹药充足的时候也能与敌人火拼，最好能找到遮挡物如:家具、冰箱之类的，这样不会死得太惨，后期关卡设定上就有陷阱了，只不过都是低级陷阱，试探1,2次基本上能解决，此外加入了特殊敌人，不仅能复活还能远程魔法攻击，其中还有自动复活的敌人比较恶心，需要打碎特定物品才能阻止复活，总的来说这游戏第一次玩很有乐趣，新鲜感强，关卡也有创意，通关后虽然解锁了高难度，但是设定上都有所了解，其它毫无亮点，目前知道的区别就只有每关增加了敌人数量而已，重玩需谨慎。

33171354.review:
Overall, one of the best games I've ever played. The atmosphere had a real 80's feel to it and the story line was incredible (if the concept was expanded to a book, I'd read it). The enemies are easy enough to handle at first, but the later stages can prove challenging, especially as you're a "one-hit-kill". And the gore, oh the gore, how I remeber my first headshot: the zombie's head exploding, fragments flying in every direction as blood splatters up the wall. I must also mention the music: the tracks are selected to fit the level perfectly, funky music for a funky level, grim music for a grim level. If they don't make a sequel then I'll end up a skeleton (you'll get the joke if you've played the game). 
10/10 Good job, Duncan

33118127.review:
Deadbolt is like a mix bewteen Hotline Miami and Gunpoint, it has the fast paced, difficult, gory gameplay of Hotline Miami, balanced with the clever, punishing, and intuitive level design of Gunpoint.  It doesn't exceed either of these games in these areas, but it certainly makes a good attempt. 

The only issues I have with the game is it's short length, and boring progression system. The length in my opinion is balanced out with the difficulty and the fair amount of replayability, the progression system (if you can call it that) however is undeniably under developed. In my opinion it shouldn't even be in the game, and instead scrapped for rewards from individual levels. The system consists of one merchant who sells primary and secondary weapons. The big issue is how few guns there are, and how useless most of them are. You only need to buy one or two throughout the game, and even then it's completely possible to just ignore them entirely.

All in all, the second commercial effort for Hoopoo is pretty good, but not great, especially compared to their first. The game is completely carried on it's level design, and even that isn't perfect.  A heasatant reccomendation at full price, but a whole hearted one if you can nab it on sale. Worth your time, but maybe not your money. 8/10

32982946.review:
在第一部作品雨中冒险大获成功之后，获得了充足资金的Hopoo Games 投入了第二部作品DEADBOLT的开发，就和工作室的上一部作品一样，DEADBOLT继承了Hopoo games精致的像素画面，同样由Chris Christodoulou操刀的杰出原声带，以及不一样的玩法。DEADBOTL可以被粗略的概括为Gunpoint、Hotline Miami、和Mark of the ninja的合体（如果以上三部作品你都玩过的话）。

  DEADBOLT是一款横版潜行射击游戏，和迈阿密热线一样需要眼明手快的精准谋杀，同样一击即死的脆弱主人公，精致的关卡设计与多样化的敌人种类，还有永远不嫌多的枪。但不同的是DEADBOLT使用了2D横板画面来展现这些元素，同时加入了一部分潜行，在DEADBOLT中只要主人公身处黑暗之中，距离稍远的敌人就看不到你也不会开枪。玩家可以通过关灯或者射击灯泡来制造黑暗，激活定时微波炉来吸引敌人的注意，使用游戏环境中比较多见的掩体来和敌人刚枪，或者用通风管道通往别的位置，在某种程度上降低了难度又维持了精准杀戮所带来的爽快感。笔者通关过迈阿密热线1和2，个人觉得迈阿密热线1代的难度较低，二代某些关卡的难度又过高，DEADBOLT因为潜行和掩体以及关卡内传送能力的导入，让难度和快感始终维持在了一个比较平均的点上，和迈阿密热线一样玩家也有可能会在某一关内一次又一次的死亡，但在DEADBOLT的这个过程中玩家能够根据死亡的经验选择更为多样化的行动路线，而不是像迈阿密热线中那样寄希望于自己小宇宙爆发的超常发挥，在大多数情况下只能用更快更准的枪法去直面敌人，这也是两款游戏不一样的魅力。


all in all, just buy every game of hopoo games! do it now!

32932382.review:
Great game, feels fluid and fast-paced. I see a lot of similarities with Hotline Miami. I want to warn you tho - controls aren't really well-made. For example, to both enter and pick up weapon you have to press "E". Not hold, but press: and for both actions. That means if you just so happen to kill an enemy right above the vent or in the doorway - say goodbye to that vent\doorway, since character will most likely pick a weapon, whether you need it or not (and not go into the vent or close the door). In controls I didn't see options to separate those buttons, which would be important in a fast-paced game like this. Another bad design decision - when you warp through the vents, with lights off you can barely see your enemies, if at all. That is especially true for a skeleton behind a cover or a pistol-equipped vampire. So sometimes I end up looking so damn hard, but not being able to find them. And then they surprise and instakill me after I get out of the vent, just because they are pretty much invisible during the vent travel. Also sometimes to kill a brute skeleton it takes 4 hits with scythe, sometimes 2 (I count a "hit" whenever their sprite lights up for a brief moment). Which is surprisingly random, and in a bad way, considering how much of a gap it is. Also sometimes you can shoot right through landminer skeleton if you shoot him point blank, even though you're clearly facing him on a screen. And one of the stages was pretty frustrating (veeery close to the endgame). You get pinned by 2 gunners and one big skeleton with a revolver, and then your entire control schemes changes to basically "press any button to die and have to redo all your progress". Stealth is also a bad idea in that stage since none of the lights can be turned off. Which is kinda unfair in my opinion.

 That type of issues caused me a lot of death and frustration during some levels, so game definetely won't go unstained in my memory. So be prepared for them if you want to play this game.

 Otherwise, it's pretty good. Pretty much all stuff I read about it before purchase is true - you can stealth a lot of the time, or straight up go full-guns blazing if you have the lightning-speed reaction. It's not "always" possible, but most of the time both are valid options.

I'm glad I gave it a go, especially for the price the game is asking. Altho, I can only very barely recommend the game because of frustrating game design decisions made above.

Ce jeu est vraiment très réussi et mérite bien plus de visibilité. 

Pour vous donner une idée globale du gameplay, il s'agit plus ou moins un mélange d'Hotline Miami et de Gunpoint (deux très chouette jeux). Préparez-vous à mourir encore et encore, à expérimenter chaque alternative et à exploser moult crânes avant de parvenir au bout d'un niveau. En somme, du Die and Retry.
Le tout baigné dans un univers assez opaque et une OST de très grande qualité (sans doute le même compositeur de Risk of Rain vu les ressemblances), donnant au tout une ambiance singulière plutot macabre.
Le scénario est également étonnement prenant.

La durée de vie est assez modeste mais correcte ; 3 chapitres de 9 missions chacunes (il me semble) et on y trouve une certaine rejouabilité (merci les succès et le Workshop).

Un titre qui, de mon point de vue, a assurément sa place dans la bibliothèque des fans du genre.

32678876.review:
This game was a very unexpected treat. I got it from a humble bundle, and it wasn't for this game whatsoever. 

But, I really enjoyed it. It feels a BIT like Hotline Miami in that it can (KEYWORD CAN, but probably not always meant to be) be pretty fast paced, it's noire-ish and gritty, it's gorey and satisfying to kill people, and its also kind of trial and error at times too. 

It certainly has flaws as well. I had a black screen on start up that I had to fix that was apparently due to windows 10 (I've been told) and the fix was literally just changing a 1 to a 0 in options.ini. I feel like that's something that could have been fixed by now. Not a huge issue, but it certainly sends a bad impression when a game doesn't start up. 

Sometimes as well, the mechanics can be a bit clunky. If a gun is directly next to a door, for example, it can be really hard to close the door, and at times you really need to close doors to be protected since you die in one hit. 

Other than the game mechanics, my favorite part is the overall world and tone and writing and junk. You play in a noire-ish city but it's all like monsters from hell and whatevs. You got Clubbing Vampires and things like Greaser Satans (I love Greaser Satans so much) and it's really cool. The writing itself is really simple, really short, but powerful and to the point, and I really respect that. 

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/319991423149539340/327792922130907147/Deadbolt_screenshot.png just a little example. You can also see there's not many cases of said writing.

It's not a perfect stealth game by any means, but it was really enjoyable to play. Expect some trial and error crap, don't expect the best game, and I think you'll be in for a pretty nice time if that's what you're into. It's not a particularly long game, so how much you'd want to pay for it is up to you. I'd say around 5 bucks give or take. Good game, I liked it a lot more than I thought I would.

If there's one word I would use to describe this game it's "Satisfying".
10/10

32550060.review: This game is like Hotline Miami and Gun Point's conservative middle brother. Where HLM wants you to be reckless (by punishing you for being too careful,) and Gun Point makes planning a necessity... this game is a brilliant mixture of both, in which your ability to quickly dispatch enemies while being carful about is rewarded. This game is great even if you like the high-octain insanity of HLM, or the slow, meticulous planning of Gun Point because you fell like such a tactical bad ass in every level.
