32169353.review:
Hopoo's DEADBOLT is a game I slept on for a very long time.  I had heard good things about it and picked it up on a whim.  One day I finally decided it was time to play, but before I installed it I glanced at the store page and realized it didn't have controller support so I opted to play something else instead.  There's nothing wrong with keyboard and mouse, but lately I've preferred to sit back and relax with a gamepad.  I'm glad I didn't initially notice the lack of controller support when purchasing the game because I may have ended up missing out.

It's probably best to know as little about the story as possible going in to this game.  The storytelling is vague at best, and it would be easy to play through the entire game and only end up with a superficial understanding of what happened.  The meat of it is told through tapes that can randomly drop from fallen foes.  The least detailed but still useful description I can give is that you play as a character that receives missions from a mysterious source.

Missions can have one of several different objectives.  You either have to collect information, assassinate a target, or kill everyone at a location.  Strategy is required as ammunition is limited and taking a single hit means death.  Completing missions calls for tactics such as shooting out lights, traveling through ventilation ducts, creating distractions, taking cover from fire by hiding behind objects, and making sure you have the right weapons equipped.  Trial and error is often involved, but there are many different ways to accomplish the goal.  After finishing each mission you obtain currency which can be used to purchase new weapons for your arsenal.  Your loadout consists of a primary and secondary weapon. They can be changed a the start of each mission by accessing the trunk of your car.  After killing starts it is no longer possible to access the trunk, but generally there are other weapons available in each stage.

While playing I was reminded of a long lost era of gaming.  The gameplay felt eerily similar to something I would have played on Newgrounds in the early 2000s.  Maybe there was a game where you played as a heavily armed stick figure and had to take out groups of enemy stick figures in a stealthy manner?  Either way, the presentation here is far better than anything I recall playing during that period.  The soundtrack is awesome and although the graphics are simplistic they successfully help give each chapter its own unique feel.  Some of the maps are creative not only in the artistic sense, but in the different strategic options they provide.

As someone that doesn't usually play stealth oriented games, I was surprised at how much fun I had playing.  It doesn't take long to complete and most players will probably be able to finish the game within 5-7 hours depending on how much they play around.  For additional replayability there is an unlockable hard difficulty, a map editor, and quite a few player created custom maps available for download in the workshop.  I'd recommend DEADBOLT to anyone looking for a stylish and relatively straightforward stealth action game.

[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/25660729-CelerySpin/]Like the review? Follow my curator page to see my thoughts on other games.[/url]

32162865.review: A somewhat short experience, but a good one. DEADBOLT balances the knife's edge between fast-paced gunplay and tactical stealth approaches, set in a seedy underworld buried in conspiracy. Levels are learned through trial and error, so get used to a cycle of dying and improving your next run. Certainly worth your time and money.

32122749.review:
My hours on this game just go to show exactly how much time and effort I've put into 100%-ing this game. Still haven't done it. I suck.
Still, the game is very enjoyable. I expected nothing less from Hopoo Games. I played Risk of Rain, loved it. Then I heard about this game, and I instantly HAD to buy it.
The game has done its job, being extremely difficult and still staying fun. I've gotten pissed off at it more than I should, but I still find myself coming back to play it.
The gameplay is really fun, with each level having multiple ways to go about it. I've probably come up with 3 different plans for each level.
The story starts off simple. You, the Reaper, doing whatever your fireplace tells you to do. Most of this involves taking out gangs of undead, Zombies, Vampires and Skeletons. But as you collect casette tapes, the story of the entire world gets more fleshed out. Honestly, I felt sad for some of the people in the casettes. But, they're undead, so they must be killed.
Here's the real thing that sold me on loving the game, however: the music. My God, the music. Chris Christodoulou has done an amazing job, yet again. (If you don't know who he is, he's the same guy that made Risk of Rain's soundtrack, again one of the main selling points for me) He creates a perfect mixture of atmosphere and action, which makes the game that much more enjoyable.
It has its fair share of bugs, and a few issues with lag, but that doesn't happen often (for me, at least).
All in all, I seriously reccomend this game.

Deadbolt is a supernatural 2D hitman game. The story is secondary to the "sequence" of busting into a place and slaughtering everyone without getting murdered by Cerberus dogs and wraith rushers. I enjoyed this game enough to want to come back to it everyday until I finished, so I'm giving it a "Yes"--but be wary, watch some gameplay vids to see if it's the sort of thing you like.

Short game, but fun. Two of my hours are AFK, and one hour is the final boss (too much scythe, so my headshot skills were whack).

31831987.review:
昨天给室友推荐游戏，我就打开库存一个个给他介绍，突然发现这个游戏，虽然只有这几个小时，但我觉得自己真的欠deadbolt一篇评测。 

去年暑假一出就买的游戏，别问我为什么买要是你你不会后悔的

去年暑假大一的自己去支教，分到一个乡里。发现那个地方离最近的镇都得每天早上等6点的大巴才能到我知道很绝望……要不是村支书老爷爷照顾我们这几个大学生还真的很难能用电脑……支教闲暇之余可以去村支书家蹭wifi（唯一的wifi啊唯一的到现在还特别感谢村支书一家从头到尾一直以为我在备课233333）
干完活，吃完饭，村支书都会很热情各种水果招待还特意给我们装了空调（暑假半天40度(ಥ_ಥ)），我这才安下心来，
但作为一个sbeamer，怎么可能没有游戏，于是就打算弄个游戏来。

由于重新装了机器我得重新安装steam和游戏，但情况是
我们20个人用一个WiFi，摊下来最高速才500kps 库里面的游戏都太大，自己白天上课只有晚上能玩游戏，这就很尴尬。

于是就有了这个游戏
像素游戏小，那当然是坠吼地，我待在村支书家门口顶着蚊虫高温感觉要上天地蹭WiFi到晚上11点终于下载好了，从此这个支教有了盼头。

每天一下课就回办公室(也就是村支书楼下)开始打游戏
随便（但认真地）说说游戏
打击系统很棒呀，你没有犯错的机会，武器不多不少刚刚好，敌人够你打一天的了。
游戏创意很吸引我。（一个人不钻下水道怎么可能百人斩？）
可玩性很高，虽然像素游戏但贼好玩

就这样一个暑假支教，晚上一直在打小手枪
空调炸了我在打小手枪
学生打架了我在打小手枪
上课了我在打小手枪（不不不我太敬业了）
吃饭了我在打小手枪

一个暑假过去了，游戏早已通关。
回到家我把它卸载了，开始是不想去回忆那么辛苦那么累的支教。
现在想想，这个游戏真的陪我度过了最困难的一次人生经历呢

最后，
原价略贵，打折请入

end   2017/05/19

31749323.review:
So, yeah. Deadbolt.

I looked at the screenshots, read the description. Steath/Action game? Sounds cool! Bought, installed... let's take a look.

Graphics, Visuals:
Because it's pixel graphics. Each to their own, I personally like it. The blood effects are quite amazing for a game like this to be honest.

Sound:
Music is top notch! It adds to the atmosphere of the game.
Sound design is very decent.

Story:
You're a reaper, just doing your job helping the undead to go where they belong. But you find out there is more than that to it.

Gameplay:
You can choose what to do and which weapons you use. That's really cool! Whether it's swinging around that scythe or headhunting with a revolver, the only limit are the weapon choices. You can lure enemies to doors to surprise them with a shotgun blast into their face, or shoot their heads off with a suppressed 9mm pistol while hiding in shadows. You will also find some weapons that are exclusive to the level during gameplay. If you fail, you stand up and try again. You can solve the levels in different ways, sometimes with unexpected results.

Enemies:
Zombies, Vampires, Demons and Skeletons. Vampires are the most annoying because of their heavier units have this revive crap.

Conclusion:
Unfortunately, I found this game short. Kind of a bummer, I would've enjoyed more missions to play. Give this game a try if you're into something like the Hitman series.

Also featuring a unique storyline / angle, and catchy music you won't mind re-hearing over and over again as you die die die.

Great fun.  Recommend.

First I was disappointed that it did not support a pad, since that is how I found the devs's previous game (Risk of Rain) most comfortable (so much so that I prefer both the vita and PS4 versions, vita because it is portable, PS4 because it synchronizes saves with the Vita version), and I thought this would play in a similar way.

Then I realized that it did not for good reasons. 
This would not work quite as well  with a pad for the reason that you really need both speed AND precision. This game plays more or less like a bastard child between Hotline Miami and Gunpoint, but... The enemies, even if they are goddamn brainless undead, have better reaction times than the hotline miami  enemies.

It does feel somewhat unfair at times, they can take many hits (the regular enemies can die in one well placed headshot), but you die in ONE. But like Hotline Miami, it feels exhilarating to have a flow planned and executing it so that everything dies except you.

While Risk Of Rain was all about knowing the general varying layouts, since it randomized elements from  the levels, this one is all about optimizing your routes on the static levels.
They are fantastic. 

Please play this game.

The soundtrack is completely amazing, as well. 
Please get this game's soundtrack.

31545683.review:
Very good, with a few minor quibbles about the controls. It's a good 4-6 hours long with some extra if you want to try for achievements.

This is a puzzle murder game. Most levels involve figuring out the right order to deal with your targets and acquire the weapons you need. You generally can't kick in the door and start shooting because you die in 1 hit, and many enemies need a few shots to take down. You also need weapons found in the level, as you can't be bothered to bring extra rounds.

There is a rating system for each level that I don't think works that well, but it gives some replay ability to the game. You don't seem to be able to acquire more souls that way though.  

Minor Quibble. You can buy new weapons, but there is no refund system. If you spend your money (souls) poorly you are out of luck. Pro-tip: Buy the Knife. It's the only secondary weapon you need. I liked the Tactical SMG as a primary weapon. It had a lot of shots, even if they were not that powerful. The Scythe is sometimes incredible and sometimes utterly useless depending on the level.

Larger Quibbles. You press W to use stairs, going up or down. You press E to enter vents AND as your general "Use Key." W should have been used for stairs and vents. That would leave E for actions. There were plenty of times I wanted to enter a vent but ended up picking up a sledge-hammer. The R key is also rarely used for secondary actions, which is awkward and you don't use it much. You also cannot change weapons while in a vent, which killed me so many times.

31376969.review:
[h1]か弱い死神さんの愉快な死にゲー[/h1]
…いややっぱ愉快じゃねえわ。死にすぎてハゲるわ。主人公に髪ないけど。

落ちてる武器を使って亡者どもを全員ぶち殺すゲーム。
高難易度かつ血がいっぱい出る以外は「Gunpoint」そっくり。でも主人公の能力が強化されたりはしない。
主人公はどんな攻撃でも食らえば即死。ショットガンの一部が足に当たっただけで全身バラバラになって死ぬ。

ラスト付近で出る、マップをまたぐ長いミッション以外は、死んだら最初からやり直しというマゾ仕様。
とはいえ動きが最適化されてくると意外と難なく抜けられたりするのが本作である。
「何度も死んで試行錯誤と記憶で対処する」過程が楽しめる人にオススメ！

[h1]評価点[/h1]
・ドアをノック→敵が開けたところで頭を一撃で撃ち抜いてやったり、バラバラに吹っ飛ばしたり。爽快。思った通りコトが進むととても気持ちが良い。もちろんその裏に幾人もの主人公が死んでいるのだが。
・戦略を考え、ひとつひとつ実行していくのが楽しい（試行錯誤が必須）。
・BGMがとてもよい。

[h1]気になった点[/h1]
・何度も死んで最初からやり直ししてるとイライラしてくる。ごめんなさい下手なのが悪いんです。
・スレッジハンマーを振り回す敵が強すぎる。（ヘッドショット連発でもなかなか死なない上に動きがやたら素早く、ショットガン or 爆発物 or 待ち伏せスレッジハンマーでなければまともに相手できないのに、こいつが大量に出てくるラストステージではショットガンもグレネードも出なくてつらい。待ち伏せしてたら他の敵に撃たれて死ぬ。一番のストレスファクター。）
・死神のカマが思ったより弱い。高かったのにィ！かっこいいから使うけどさ。
・自分の出した音や敵の発した声が「どの範囲まで届いているのか」が非常に分かり辛く、敵の反応で事後的に判明するしかない（もちろん予想・仮定はできる）のだが、武器によって音の届く範囲が全く違ううえに、音を聞いたあとの敵の行動が予測しづらいので非常に混乱する。高難易度化のためだろうか？

[h1]その他[/h1]
・本編のボリュームは少なめだが、ワークショップにユーザー制作マップがあるので長く遊ぶことは可能。
・全実績解除はかなり難しいが、7割くらいならイケる。
・イライラを感じたら休憩すること。

31176239.review:
普通难度已通关

有点像《Ninjia Mark》和《Hotline Miami》的结合体，主角一碰就死硬派风格非常喜人（？）。过关方式基本靠背版，通过一遍遍试误之后找到最合理的路线与行动方式毕其功于一役，重玩的时候一次过关感很爽。


[u]剧透警告[/u]

目前只通了一遍，《deadbolt》的剧情整体不如《Hotline Miami》丰满，但也有值得玩味的地方，在这里简单说一下大体的剧情，因为本身没有注意看过场语音，所以可能会有不少疏漏，期待大家的补充。

作为reaper的主角，从家里的壁炉中的火焰接任务——那团火焰就是他老板的化身（[spoiler]真身是一根顶着大蜡烛的大骷髅[/spoiler]）。

在第一章僵尸篇里，主角发现绿皮小僵尸们正在吸食一种叫ash的东西（毒品？），而逐渐追查下去，发现是由吸血鬼帮（『千年皇室』）卖给他们的。但在追查吸血鬼们的时候，主角发现许多吸血鬼因为吸食ash过量自身变成了ash，而提供给他们ash的骷髅们则前来收集这些新的ash。


在进一步的调查中，主角发现是骷髅们的首领在伙同恶魔们，利用ash收集能量，以开启一道通往『温暖之地』的传送门，并且最终真的成功了，将传送去了未知的地方，于是主角跟着冲进了大门，到达了一幢大宅中。而在大宅前的水井下面，则见到了一直以来给他任务的老板——一个顶着大蜡烛的骷髅——他们提到了一个叫做ibazan的人（这里我没仔细看，到底是指骷髅首领还是他们崇拜的『邪神』），并且最终主角去解决骷髅帮的老大（他会不断复生，每次都会带出更多小弟）。而在boss临死之际，他对主角说的却是『对不起，朋友……』两人之间的关系也很耐人寻味。


而在整个剧情当中，一直在提到『warmth』这个词，主角们面对的不死族们在追求『warmth』，而主角的老板则给予了主角『warmth』，再加上我们可以把主角每次死后接关重来看做不断重生，[spoiler]那也许这个游戏也是个传火的游戏吧（笑）。[/spoiler]


总之，游戏很好玩，小品级体量，不错的操纵性和难度，值得一试！


更多剧情方面还请各位补充~

31158131.review:
·入雨冒的时候顺便看了该公司的其他作品，然后就发现了这款干爆爽的[spoiler]手残党福音[/spoiler]潜杀游戏。断断续续花了近4h后通了普通难度后在HARDMODE被虐的体无完肤，无奈跑来先写评测以示敬意。作为一款横版2D的潜入游戏，拥有上帝视角的你可以洞悉一切[spoiler]然并卵[/spoiler]。开门杀，关灯杀，[spoiler]千年杀[/spoiler]。。。等等技巧可以轻松在一个照面取敌首级。在我看来让敌人至死不明真相的暗杀快感才是这款游戏真正吸引我的地方。有时不免端着机枪正面肛，但更多还是仅凭一把小手枪背后爆头。
·老鹅曾经直播过一次，无奈太难就退款了。这款游戏的难点就在于很多人都不知道商店的存在，以至越到后面越是力不从心，白守一大堆灵魂点；其二就是习惯了正面肛的快节奏后，不管三七二十一上去就是一顿A，然而暗杀是须准度耐心二者兼备。抓住时机，一击必杀。一击不成，迅速远遁。[spoiler] 这让我想起了某些起点网文中牛X的男主们。。。[/spoiler]其三枪弹少是硬伤，尤其到了HARDMODE，补给少到可怜。
·敌方阵营让我最讨厌的莫过于狗了，近战拼不过，爆头要好几枪，在弹药不充足的情况下只能飞刀飞锤伺候。
·官方关卡有几关印象特别深刻，一个玩狙，一个玩机关。若是不能满足，没问题，创意工坊有地图。实在不行，游戏自带地图编辑器，自娱自乐。
·出装推荐：前期9mm+小刀；中后期猎颅者+锤子或镰刀+无声小口径手枪或激光枪+爆破猎枪（所谓出装大部分是用于应付未补给之前的真空时段，等胖子掉双管，蝙蝠掉机关，骷髅魔鬼掉装后基本可以实现火力再生，以战养战）
TIP：子弹不一定要用来杀人，朝天射一炮，制造声响也别有奇效
最后再说两句：一武器太少，二希望能加一个易容的技能。

31048601.review:
Fairly difficult 2d shooting game about using the environment to your advantage. Reminded me a lot of gunpoint, just a little more serious and a lot more violent. Going through each level is almost like solving a puzzle, figuring out what sequence of events is the best way of tackling/shooting any given problem. It is a slow paced game, not meant for running and gunning but slowly approaching a door and considering the possibilities before you. 

There are a couple minor issues I have, such as either bugged ai or sometimes cursing the controls. But other than wanting more, I can't anything else.

I can highly recommend this game if you enjoy a slow, almost puzzle like, action game with tense moments. Games it reminds me of, hotlight miami, gunpoint, mark of the ninja.

31028513.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]

Deadbolt is a 2D stealth shooter

+ Easy to understand and play
+ Many weapons available
+ Requires strategy
+ Can take advantage of your sorroundings in many ways (e.g., turn off lights, knock on doors)
- Annoying pop-up tips cannot be disabled

[h1]Review[/h1]

In Deadbolt you control the grim reaper and you must complete missions that usually require you to kill undead. At your disposal you have weapons and the ability to travel through tubes.

The missions are very linear and easy to understand. Most of the time you just have to kill everyone. Sometimes you just have to kill specific targets, destroy items or get information. The game is split into sections containing a set of missions. Each section has a different theme. Simple yet satisfying formula.

This game has many of weapons. You have your fists, handguns, shotguns, riffles, hammers and so on. However ammo is limited. Being a stealth shooter have to be very careful were and how you use your weapons. You must also be very precise if you want to save ammo. Aiming for the head is a good choice.

This game requires strategy to win. There's not much room for mistake since every enemy can kill you with a single hit. The best way to beat each level is to study your sorroundings and take advantage of it. For example, you can turn off the lights, knock on the door, shoot on the back and so on. Even so, the game doesn't really stop you from going commando style. If you're skilled enough you may get away with killing maybe four enemies tops in a row. It's very difficult but still possible.

One issue I have with this game is that it is constantly giving you tips on how to play it and you cannot disable this feature. It's like Microsoft's clip. Often I just want to try not so great ideas for fun and I don't want to be interrupted by a pop up giving me tips.

[h1]Update[/h1]

I have just finished the game in hard mode. In hard mode there are more enemies to kill so you have to be more efficient. I didn't know you could buy weapons until I beat the game but in hard mode that's probably a good idea. If you liked the game hard mode is worth it.

31027203.review:
You spend the game running around levels killing various undead creatures.  There's not a lot here in terms of story/character development, it's mostly an action/stealth game depending on how you want to approach missions.  There are 3 chapters in the game, each consisting of 9 missions.  You are free to replay any mission at any time.  Most missions require you to kill all undead creatures but there're several missions that have other objectives where you don't have to kill everything.  Dying during a mission places you back at the start of the mission.  Some missions have multiple parts, during those missions, you'll respawn at whichever part you're at instead of the beginning of the mission.  Most missions can be completed in anywhere from 2-3 minutes, so it's pretty rare that any given mission will take you more than 15 minutes.  Took me around 11 hours to complete the game once on normal and hard.  Vents can be used to take shortcuts around buildings.  Doors can be knocked on to lure in enemies.  Objects can be used to provide cover.  Light switches can be pressed to keep enemies from seeing you or you can just shoot out lights if you want to.  The game has several melee weapons and many guns that all feel very different from one another.  You can run around with 2 weapons at any given time.  In between missions, you can use souls that you've earned to purchase weapons from Charon that you can choose to start missions with, some of them are unique.  All of the game's achievements also provide souls for you upon completion, giving you some incentive to complete them.  Completing the game unlocks hard mode which adds more enemies to missions, introduces tougher enemies earlier in the game, or changes the placement of enemies, which changes the strategy or tactics needed to complete levels.

When the game works correctly, it's both fun and rewarding.  There are a decent variety of enemy types.  Each undead category (Zombies, Vampires, etc) have 4 types of enemies in it.  Some are melee, some use guns, some have more health, some hang out on ceilings, some hang out underground until you approach, etc.  Most enemies go down pretty easily, none are really bullet sponges.  A couple levels even include some traps for you to run into.  Each of the melee weapons have advantages and disadvantages.  The sledgehammer kills any enemy in 1 hit, but is very slow to swing, where as the knife takes a few stabs to kill enemies up close but can be thrown to instantly kill smaller enemies.  Guns due various damage depending on their types.  Big guns like the shotguns or rifles usually do more damage than smgs and pistols but also tend to have fewer rounds before they run out.  If you have a partially loaded weapon equipped and walk over a similar gun on the ground, the game loads the bullets from the gun on the ground into your gun.  Empty guns dissapear once dropped.  Each gun has it's own accuracy and your reticle will get bigger or smaller as you place it further or closer to you.  Head shots do extra damage to enemies.  Enemies will also react if they hear shooting nearby them.  You can buy silenced weapons from Charon for a more stealthy approach to missions.  Several missions have bosses on them.  Bosses tend to work just like regular enemies except with some added quirk.  None of them are bullet sponges and often go down just as easily as any other enemy.

The game has 3 issues that can occasionally be frustrating:  1. Picking up weapons, using cover, hitting light switches, opening/closing doors, and entering vents are all done by using the 'e' key.  Usually there isn't a problem with this, but some enemies drop guns when they die and these will often fall right in front of vents or light switches or doors.  So you'll go to a vent and press 'e' to hop into it and instead you accidentally pick up a weapon.  Not a big deal you think, until you press 'e' again to hop into the vent but still don't go in because picking up that weapon in front of the vent caused you to drop your equipped weapon in front of the vent, so you wind up picking up your original weapon and drop the other weapon in front of the vent again.  And now you're dead.  This will happen semi-frequently with vents you want to go in, light switches you want to hit, and doors you want to close.  I'm not sure how this issue didn't pop up during playtesting and why they don't simply allow you to assign a separate key for grabbing weapons.  2.  Closing doors is annoying.  You need to be almost on top of them to close them and often times it will close with you being on the wrong side of the door that you wanted to be on.  This can occasionally result in you getting killed.  3.  Every once and a while the game is inconsistent.  Using the mouse wheel switches between your two weapons, but sometimes you'll scroll the mouse and it won't switch.  Sometimes you'll be right on top of an object with it highlighted, press 'e' and nothing happens but you keep playing assuming that the game did whatever it was you wanted to do... that's when you realize that the game didn't bother picking up that fully loaded gun on the ground that you pressed 'e' on and you're still holding your empty gun with a melee enemy 5 feet away from you.  Now you're dead.

Good game with a couple flaws that should've been ironed out but for some reason haven't.

30973366.review:
DEADBOLT — это крайне смертоносная смесь Hitman, Splinter Cell и Hotline Miami, образец мастерского применения скудных технических и художественных средств для создания игры более атмосферной, цельной и «киношной» чем абсолютное большинство проектов, формально декларирующих подобное. При этом игра интересна не только во внешних проявлениях, но и в механике, в частных элементах игрового процесса.

Многие интересные игры погружают вас в свою астмосферу часами — DEADBOLT делает это за секунды! Ряд элементов игры покажутся родственными таковым из Gunpoint (двухмерность, стилизация, головоломки, вентиляция вместо электросетей). Однако есть ключевая разница, бездонной пропастью разделяющая эти две игры: конечная цель в DEABLOT в 95% случаев не приклеена к стене и может переместиться практически куда угодно, находу меняя обстановку на уровне - а следовательно и впечатления от процесса. Стоит отметить многообразие решений и последствий там, где Gunpoint предлагает ровно 1 маршрут (реже - целых 2). Выбранное оружие, тактика, избранные моменты действия, постоянная реакция на изменение обстановки - игрок сам складывает свою уникальную головоломку уровня.

С вышеупомянутой Spliner Cell игру роднит постоянный контроль освещенности и звука. Выбор оружия поддерживает разнообразие подходов к решению задачи. За нескромную плату известному персонажу древних мифов в распоряжении Жнеца может упасть немало средств решения поставленных задач на средней и короткой дистанции: парные именные кольты, набор револьверов, пистолеты и дробовики с глушителями и без, а также нож и молоток для работ по чьей-то физиономии. Более чем достаточный выбор позволяет постоянно разыгрывать сцены перестрелок из любимых фильмов, раз от раза приводя в полный восторг.

Четко выдержанный визуальный стиль и потрясающая музыка Криса Кристодулу (он же работал над предыдущей игрой студии - Risk of Rain) являются крепким фундаментом для сеттинга и истории, которую категорически нельзя спойлерить, зато крайне интересно обсудить! Удачно совмещена как традиционно прямая, так и косвенная подача сюжета на манер того же Dark Souls, сплетая из фактов паутину намеков и домыслов. Достаточно сказать, что зомби и упыри являются не просто удачной стилизацией, а ключевым элементом сюжета.

Отдельно отмечу игнорируемый многими Сложный режим. Враги в нем НЕ становятся толще и быстрее, зато меняются некоторые казалось бы незначительные элементы знакомых уровней. Если вы, не до конца насытившись процессом, ищите «продолжения банкета», то Сложный режим и без того чрезвычайно сложной игры - один из двух путей продлить удовольствие. Второй путь - сотни уровней из Мастерской. Правда они как правило значительно труднее Сложного режима, но опытный убийца-«торпеда» в каждой проблеме видит решение.

Итого: однозначный инди-шедевр, 10/10 с ошметками чужих мозгов на кончиках ваших пальцев.
Настоятельно рекомендуется к покупке всем, кому интересны развлечения сложнее чем «три-в-ряд». Заядлым хардкорщикам «зайдет» даже за полную цену.

30682233.review:
I hesitate to parrot the comparisons to Hotline Miami, but it's really hard not to. As someone who was disappointed with the direction that Hotline Miami 2 took in that it veered away from HLM1's think-on-your-feet gameplay into just a boring twin-stick button-mash shooter, DEADBOLT really scratched that itch left unscratched by HLM2.

The graphical style, music, and atmosphere are fantastic and easily my favorite part of the game. Music always fits the mood, and every light is perfectly placed to keep the mood up.

The gameplay itself is cool. The game is difficult, but I never once felt cheated by a death. The mechanics are easy to grasp and allow you to try different things. It's got that HLM1 feel of planning a route, trying it, getting killed, then fine-tuning your plan until it's executed flawlessly. The game adds enemies and level design variants that make each level feel and play different in ways that create a really nice difficulty curve as you play.

This game is one of the most well thought out side scrollers I've played in a while. The sheer simplicity of the game is incredible, yet there is this layer of depth that you barely notice, and once you do, the game becomes even more fun to play. 

To put it simply, the game is one of the best, and hardest, stealth side scrollers I've come across in recent memory. Each level has a multitude of ways to complete it, and given your playstyle, you can easily figure out which works best for you. The game does emphasize steath, but there is a level of run and gun that you can take to it, however, to trully feel like the badass you are meant to be, I would recommend a stealth playthrough with headshots only. Its brutal, unforgiving, but a total blast and you feel so accomplished once you've figured out the trick to getting past that one tricky level, or the best way to maximize your souls.

All in all, I would rate this game a solid 10/10, for the replayability and level jump can keep you coming back for more.

29951558.review:
DEADBOLT Is really awesome. That's been established if you've looked at the many other reviews. The soundtrack is ACES, the weapons feel glorious, 
and each
kill
feels
great.
Except when they don't. DEADBOLT is awesome for the first bit, but gradually transforms from a game where you have to see how to kill enemies without alerting others or finding the coolest way to kill stuff, to being a management game.
What are you managing? Ammo.
DEADBOLT is still fun when it starts to be more about managing ammo, but it kind of takes away from the core of what felt satisfiying. Every shot counts, but more than it probably should. This goes to the end of each level requiring you to have to assign enemies to guns, and be forced into never missing a single shot. One good example is a level with two towers you must clear in order to reach the top and kill an enemy in each one. In order to do so you have to kill two enemies in a room with precisely two shots from a shotgun, carefully execute three enemies with the remaining shells. Then you have to use another gun you picked up to kill one enemy with one shot, and pick up the only pistol able to one-shot-headshot the enemy type you face. Exit the building and move to the other, and take out four consequtive targets with only headshots as not to waste valuable ammo, and dispatch the last one by throwing a hammer at him to save a single bullet. By the time you're done with the tower, you should only have one or two bullets left in your gun, and over 50 retries in the logs. That being said it's very satisifying to do so, but it does kind of feel removed from the earlier chapters where you explode a zombie's head from 20 meters with a silenced pistol in a single shot. 

None the less, DEADBOLT is fantastic, and you should play it for the music, even if you hate the game. Which you won't.

29910374.review:
DEADBOLT is a really cool game. 

I think if I had to describe the game in just one adjective, “cool” is perfect. The soundtrack is cool, the art is cool, the gameplay is cool, the main protagonist is cool. Everything in this game is dripping with a slick style that invokes a corrupt, familiar, noir influenced world of supernatural crime and intrigue. As the motherfucking Grim Reaper himself, it’s your job to kill the targets presented by each mission, but instead wearing a hood and using a scythe (although you do get that option later), your tools of trade are a classy brown wool coat and an assortment of firearms and melee weapons.

The developer’s previous game was the excellent rogue-like Risk of Rain, and DEADBOLT is a simpler, more focused experience. Instead of the plethora of characters, items, artifacts in Risk of Rain, DEADBOLT is a streamlined 2D stealth/action hybrid game where it’s just you, your chosen loadout, and a group of supernatural monsters that need to die. The Reaper is essentially a hitman, but not the meticulously calculated, sneaky, make a target’s death look like an unfortunate accident Agent 47 type, but the shoot everyone in the face, ambushing and mowing down large groups before they can react kind, more like a John Wick or perhaps more accurately, Anton Chigurh from No Country for Old Men, silenced shotgun and all. Similar to a 2D version of Hotline Miami, combat is fast and frenetic, and the Reaper dies in one hit. However, your character has the ability to teleport between vents in a level, letting you surprise and flank enemies from behind. Being in the dark as often as possible is absolutely necessary to avoid being insta-killed by enemies, which gives you a distinct advantage as you will always be able to see them, while they can’t see you. The Reaper can also knock on doors instead of just barging in, setting up traps for enemies and drawing them away for opportunistic attacks, as well as hide behind cover for some survivability in the tense firefights.

The dark, moody soundtrack sets the mood wonderfully, and the sound design is detailed, leading to differing volumes as you move from an exterior to an interior environment. When people complain about a saturation of pixel art in indie games these days, they certainly are not talking about games like this. This is one of the titles whose presentation is enhanced by the minimalistic art, and it’s a shockingly violent game as well. I was genuinely stunned as I capped a zombie’s head from behind at close range, watching his blood and brains splatter in streaks across the wall, his headless corpse slumping down against an ajar door. The storyline, however minimal gives tantalizing glimpses at the world's lore and sets the imagination alight with a player's own speculation. I liked the story a lot, it definitely doesn't burden the game with pointless distractions, but has just enough to keep a player invested.

This game is hard as nails, but when you finally manage to complete a mission, it really does feel like you ARE the Reaper, taking out groups with precise headshots easily, disappearing into the shadows only to reappear somewhere completely unexpected. If you’re a true masochist, there is even a HARDER mode that unlocks after you complete the main campaign(which I’m pretty sure is impossible), as well as downloadable, user generated maps direct from the Steam Workshop. Hopoo Games are currently two for two in terms of fantastic entries in the indie game space, and I can’t wait to see what they come up with next.

29784828.review:
Deadbolt is an interesting 2D action/platformer where you play as the Grim Reaper and are given tasks which involve culling the recent rise of the undead in an undisclosed city. The background and the mysterious nature of the Reaper himself, his messenger, the fire, and the Gatekeeper/weapons merchant Cheron brings together an interesting take on gameplay which is similar to the platforming mechanics of Gunpoint and with combat that reminds me of the close quarters mayhem of Hotline Miami. 
Deadbolt has a large number of missions, and each one is a learning process of exactly how to do the mission. This adds a certain replayablity to the game, for players may want to return to certain missions to train their reflexes for later (and harder) stages, whislt also farming some of the easier achievements. Achievements are save-independent and give souls (currency) as rewards.
This game can be crushingly difficult, for any damage by an enemy is an instant death, so quick reflexes, planning, and a few restarts are to be expected when playing this game.
Overall, this game is hugely fun, and eventhough I got it for free through a friend, it's a blast that's worth its price.

These instrumentals add such a deeper level of immersion, atmosphere, and meaning to this game. (Plus it's pretty cool how when you are outside a building it becomes muffled.

29753862.review:
Take the twitch gameplay and an equivelantly trippy setting to Hotline Miami and place with it the graphical style and puzzel solving of Gunpoint, and you have yourself Deadbolt.

Whether or not you like this game is going to depend on a few things, becuase those who like the game love it, and those who don't, hate it.

It requires both puzzle solving and twitch skills. If you're just a twitch player, you're going to feel like you're banging your head against a brick wall, if you're just a puzzle solver, you're going to see how to get over the wall but not have the reflexes to do so.

You will die, you will die over and over and to those who like Dark Souls that probably sounds like a dare. Know that this game is less forgiving than Dark Souls, because one hit, one shot and you start that whole level over. Enemies are acurate and hitscan. You don't get to dodge, you have to make sure they can't shoot you in the first place.

The game may be unforgiving but it is fair. Levels always start the same way and enemies have predicatble behavior. You're never screwed by way of RNG, if you're screwed it's because you messed up.

If this sounds good for you, congrats! You'll find a rewarding game with a story that's fantastic if you peice it together. An awesome sound track and a feeling of bad assery when you finally get back to your car at the end of a level.

If this did not all sound good to you, that's fair. This will not be for everyone just as Dark Souls and Hotline Miami are not for everyone.

Edit: Spelling

29725837.review:
[h1]Ви є доказом життя після смерті? Тоді ми йдемо до вас[/h1]

Як не крути, але прогрес не стоїть на місці. Графоній прокачується, сцени в деяких ААА проектах вже затикають за пояс кінематограф, геймплей перетворюють в солянку з усіх можливих жанрів, а сюжет закручують до рівня бестселерів у світі літератури. Покупець стає вимогливішим до продукту. Тепер йому мало просто цікавого задуму і непоганої механіки, яка здатна вирвати з буденного життя і перенести в свій світ. Гасла із серії «граю, бо це в тренді» відвертають увагу від деяких дійсно непоганих проектів, які хоч і не знімають зірок з неба, але тим не менше дарують задоволення від першого рівня і до останнього.

Під час перегляду черги рекомендованих ігор (любов до халяви колись таки вилізе мені боком) я знайшов Deadbolt. На перший погляд – нічого особливого. Звичайна інді, яких зараз море. Але після повного проходження я не можу не погодитись, що родзинка в грі є. І достатньо велика, аби витрясти з мене 9 годин часу на проходження основного набору місій. 

Коротко про сюжет. Наш протеже – жнець. І не той, що в полі косить, а той хто відправляє перевіряти, чи є життя після смерті. Проте наші вороги, скоріше за все, і так в курсі, бо валити нам доведеться виключно нечисть. З кожним рівнем ми будемо просуватись все далі у нетрі інтриги одного з лідерів потойбічної тусовки, який хоче потіснити нашого «працедавця».

В геймплеї є певні нюанси. По-перше, наш герой не безсмертний. Вороги запросто відправляють нас на початок рівня, достатньо лише потрапити їм на очі. Викиньте з голови всі шаблони, а-ля «нечисть має битись врукопашну». В більшості випадків на гравця, який вдерся через парадний вхід, націлять стволи і зроблять решето з пістолетів, автоматів і рушниць. Якщо опоненти не мають вогнепальної зброї, то в якості компенсації вони гасають на надзвукових швидкостях. Здавалось – безперспективняк, адже гра притримується принципу «так багато ідіотів і так мало патронів». Але ігрова механіка і дизайн рівнів дарує гравцю ультимативну плюшку – альтернативність. Постукати в двері і виманити ворогів, тихо зайти в тили через вентиляцію і економно роздати всім свинець в макітри; знищити джерело освітлення і прибрати ворогів по одному; нагло вломитись з парадного входу, роздати хедшоти остовпілим ворогам, зайняти укриття і перестріляти підкріплення. Варіантів проходження – вагон, вантажівка, три відра і ще контейнер від «кіндер сюрпризу» на додаток. Не може не тішити той факт, що використання сірої речовини в довбешці позитивно впливає на подолання рівнів. Навіть маючі посередні снайперські здібності гру можна пройти, якщо ретельно планувати свої дії.

Напруженню мозкової діяльності сприяють і вороги: зомбі, скелети, вампіри і інша нечисть адекватно реагують на гамір, тіла своїх товаришів і навіть вимкнене світло. Більш того, кожна категорія ворогів має унікальних мобів. Наприклад вампірів є три види: з вогнепальною зброєю, спритні жіночки з катанами і до чорта живучі гади, які до того ж перероджуються, якщо гравець вчасно не роздушить ємність, яка зв’язана з істотою. В наявності є і боси, які перевірять, чого ви навчились при подоланні попередніх рівнів.

Пара слів про наші аргументи для спілкування з усіляким потойбічним мурлом. Арсенал не підкачав: є револьвери, звичайні пістолети, гранатомети, рушниці тощо. Кожен знайде щось на свій смак і стиль гри. Варто згадати, що частину іграшок ми можемо придбати за отримані від проходження душі і екіпірувати на початку рівня.

Музика доволі непогана. Принаймні не виникало бажання поставити щось своє під час проходження.

Графоній піксельний. Графодрочери плюються кислотою. В якості плюсу - гра доволі жорстока: потужна зброя рве ворожин на клапті, а влучні стрільці матимуть чудове оформлення стін у багряних відтінках.

Висновок. Дас іст гут. Хоч де-не-де я і бачив відгуки а-ля «Hotline Miami, тільки в профіль», не ведіться. Єдине, що об’єднує дві гри – “one shot – one kill” для головного персонажу. Даний стелс екшн також виправдає кожну витрачену копійку і секунду за умови придбання. А редактор рівнів і прикручений Steam Workshop гарантуватиме довге життя проекту.

29724464.review: Hotline Miami's calm and collected little brother.

29715866.review:
A mixture of several mythologies, fantasy and ultraviolence à la Hotline Miami create the unique setting for Deadbolt - a 2D stealth game where you play the reaper reclaiming the undead.
Although that's just half-true, because depending on your skill you can play with guns blazing or without making a sound, either way it's incredibly good fun. 

Challenging, but not impossible.
Most indies these days are [i]hard[/i] and Dark Souls made difficulty a selling point for videogames, but often times it feels like difficulty is just there to water down the content. 
Deadbolt on the other hand requires a calm hand and good planning. I've never been frustrated, because I knew I could do better and even then the game respects your time and effort. Something I've never seen before. When you fail a couple of times - and you will - the game tells you to take a break, reconsider your strategy or gives you a hint. I've seen people on the forums outraged, because they felt babysat, but I really appreciate the notion.    

The pixel art appeared simple at first, having played Hyper Light Drifter and the like, but it is that simplicity that grew on me with excellent, fluid animations and a necessary minimalism to give you the canvas to splatter zombie brains on. 
The level design gives you multiple ways to complete missions and offers a variety that won't bore you, constantly introducing new enemies which will mix up the gameplay and force you to adapt. It keeps the game challenging and interesting.
The story is cryptic, which seems en vogue these days, but offers enough clarity to let you follow and actually care about it, so that the apex doesn't leave you completely cold.

For me Deadbolt was a huge suprise. I had so much fun that I actually replayed levels after beating it, which is extremely rare for me. I'm glad when I even beat a game in the first place. I highly recommend it.

29711763.review:
The lovechild of Gunpoint and Hotline Miami but better than both: a 2D platform "stealth" game that rapidly devolves into frantic shooting.

"Stealth" in scare-quotes because to me that means that the gold standard is to remain completely undetected. That isn't even possible in this game: a better description is that it's a speedrun game of alarm management. You're not trying to carefully prowl around unseen, you are trying not to be visible long enough that you are shot and killed. These are not the same. A common pattern is to deliberately show yourself so that enemies take up defensive positions, then travel through a duct to take them from behind. Or wait behind a door to shoot when it is opened. Or just take cover and commence a gunfight: wait until they reload and shoot them in the head.

The game doesn't hold your hand and so a lot of strategic lessons need to be worked out from first principles. For me, the result was that for my first two hours or so I wasn't very happy. Part of the problem is that a stealth approach does sort of work through the Zombie Kingz missions, particularly if you purchase a weapon like the suppressed 9mm pistol. But later enemies require far too much damage and it becomes necessary to use louder weapons. Eventually it becomes clear that there are no actual consequences to discovery.

It's a smooth engine (feels like the same one previously used for Risk of Rain), nice artwork (a really wonderful level of character in the individual sprites given the pixelated style), and a great soundtrack. There's even a little bit of plot. The difficulty curve is uneven and some elements are under-used (e.g. traps), but there's hope that player-built custom levels can fill that void. 

Hard mode is not that much more difficult than normal and if you didn't fudge your way through then it should be a nice challenge. 

The gameplay is very polished, and most of the criticisms I had initially were because I was playing badly and didn't realize it. 

Ultimately, most of my problems with the game are minor annoyances around menus etc., such as that if you quit after failing a mission, next time you start it up you have to talk to the flames again. The level menu also does not default to the next unlocked mission even though 99% of the time that's what you will want to play. If you drop a weapon next to a grate then the context changes to "pick up weapon" rather than "enter grate", which can be frustrating. Nothing big, but it could do with some updates to usability.

29609585.review:
I completed this game's main campaign and some of the custom levels.

I was drawn to Deadbolt because of its main marketing image, a strangely shaped skeleton seen through a peephole. Watching the trailers left me unsure as it looked like Gunpoint (One of my favorite indie games) but with less flash. From what I could tell the protagonist Reaper barely had any unique abilities whatsoever. This simplicity ended up being what made this game so great for me. Reaper has one special ability, He can become mist and travel through the ventilation and plumbing of a stage. Beyond that he fights with normal punches, hammers and firearms.

Each level consists of a cross-section view of a building filled with enemies for you to deal with similar to Gunpoint. This means you can see nearly every enemy's movement and whether or not they're coming for you. Planning is a very big part of Deadbolt but the great part is that it doesn't have to be. Similar to games like Hotline Miami or 'Not a Hero' Things can go wrong at any moment and you'll have to make split second decisions or get shot in the face. Reaper, by the way, can only take one hit from anything before dying. You can play it as a really frantic action game or you can play it as a strategic stealth game, or you can play it as a mix. And unlike most stealth games nowadays you aren't punished for taking one approach over another. There are only 10-15 enemy types and most levels only use a couple of them each until late in the game. However this means that enemies are easy to identify and their basic reactions and how much damage they will need to go down are obvious from one glance at a stage. You are given a couple options to help approach each challenge such as knocking on doors, prompting an enemy to come open the door or turning off the lights to hide your presence until the enemy gets really close. Every gun has very limited ammo meaning you can't afford to just pump bullets into a room. Most weapons don't pierce either so if you try to take own too many enemies with one weapon you'll run out of ammo or be taken out while shooting someone else. Headshots kill quicker so there is some skill involved even in the most strategic playstyle. 

A variety of weapons can be purchased with 'souls' that you get from beating levels and completing acheivements. The wonderful thing is that almost any weapon can be bought soon after the shop opens with the most expensive ones only requiring you to wait another level or two. There are no 'Super weapons' that can only be used on a handful of the last levels due to price. Each one has a clear purpose and playstyle intended with it and there are no superior versions of one weapon. So if you kick ass at headshots, buy the pistol that will one hit kill any enemy with a headshot. If you plan to go busting down the doors but dont want to alert everybody all at once you can get a silenced shotgun. The greatest thing is that every weapon is balanced. None of them are the best in every situation. Even the most expensive weapon, the scythe which can one hit kill any basic enemy, had plenty of moments where I had absolutely no way to implement it into my strategy. Beyond that every weapon you can buy besides the scythe has limited ammo that can't be found in the stages so all it does is change how you start the level, the rest you have to get creative with whats available to you. I also want to say that not a single level from the first to last had me thinking "if only I purchased X weapon" I felt every single stage could be reasonably started using the default magnum. 

The game's story is simple, you're an underworld hitman (literally) trying to unravel a conspiracy involving all the gangs made up of various undead monsters. I love that theres no 'pretentious indie game message' that I have to understand to 'enjoy' the game. You can certainly dissect some of the dialogue but the story is perfectly serviceable with the brief bits we're given. 

The Art and Music are both fantastic. The art while simple, just oozes stlye. Most areas are dark gray or white but this helps keep the area cleaner so you can see yourself and your opponents faster. A lot of games like this I often feel are too busy and things get lost in the background but not in Deadbolt. Enemies have different death animations depending on how you kill them and a good headshot splattering blood all over the monotone rooms is very satisfying. Each of the four gangs is given its own unique look as well. The Zombies have a 'gangsta/hoodlum' thing going, the Vampires have a 'sleazy/sexy' nightclub look and the skeletons have a proper mafia design. As they are fought in that order it really gives the impression of working your way up the ladder of a crime syndicate. The music is possibly even better than the game. I am usually the type to listen to a podcast or some of my own library instead of a game's music. I just get bored of a game's soundtrack after a while and often times game music isn't something I would actually listen to on a road trip or something. Deadbolt however kept my ears focused on it the entire time. From smooth jazz, to club beats to metal the soundtrack is diverse and there are quite a few songs in it as well. I bought the album soon after finishing the game which I feel is the best recommendation I can give. 

The game is not easy, not at all, but its simplicty lets you learn it much faster than most games so that the levels can get creative much faster than they would if your character had a billion bloody moves to learn. Even though it is challenging, it isnt frustrating in the way games like Hotline Miami or rogue-likes can sometimes get where it feels like things are really overwhelming and almost luck based. Deadbolt does a wonderful job of finding that sweet spot for me where it isnt boring me but it isnt pissing me off either; I'm having honest fun facing each challenge in the game.

Maybe the greatest testament I can personally give for how good this game's gameplay is that I actually downloaded and played player made levels. I never do this because I'm usually burnt out on a game by the time I finish it to want to play something that may or may not be good, but Deadbolt actually left me wanting more, I would pay up instantly for some kind of DLC for this game. Now I have to hope they release a T-shirt

Summary:
+Simple but varied gameplay
+Stylish
+Soundtrack
+All playstyles encouraged
+All weapons are useful
~Not short, not long
-Occaisonally can be hard to interact with the correct item if they are on top of each other
-So far no T-shirt available for purchase

29531791.review:
DeadBolt is a game where you are a Reaper who kill creatures of the underworld.
It's a sidescrolling game that has a mix of action and reflexion, similar to some Devolver Games like Hotline Miami or Not A Hero (if you're a fan of those you can pretty much buy this one eye closed).
This one was made by Hopoo Games, the guys behind Risk of Rain. Now that I'm done stating the obvious I'll tell you what's great about it.
It's nice tightly packed game, with both an awesome sound design and an awesome soundtrack. Guns feel satisfying to use, headshot feels great, and I'm still playing the OST on youtube. Most of the map will require you to think twice before even starting the violence, letting you imagine all kind of schemes before you execute them. It's a really fun experience set in an interesting mafia/underworld theme.
The graphics are trademark to hopoo with desaturated vibe, color scheme that look like variant of puke, and really satisfying explosion/splatter effect.
It's smooth, got a great attention to details, amazing level design and I cannot recommend it enough.

29470595.review:
[h1]Underworld Hitman [/h1] 

DeadBolt is great fast paced side scrolling shooter, you have options to stealth through levels and take each enemy out individually or you blast your way through the levels hoping that the enemies don’t react in time. The story and characters of the game isn’t that strong but they are enough to keep you interested.

The guns are all different as the damage noise and range changes for everyone, and you do have to be conservative with ammo. I personally found myself using melee weapons most of the time as throwing them is so powerful and can take out most enemies in one hit.

The levels are nicely laid out with most have multiple entrances. There are many ways to tackle each level and searching around is almost essential, there are many things in the environment you can use to hide behind or draw out enemies. I found myself never using the cover system as enemy ai wasn’t that great.

The models in the game where quite nicely made although there was only one per enemy type, DeadBolt had some nice detail in the maps and I was in love with the design of the final level.

There is replayability to get all the weapons and 5 star each level. The best feature is the mission editor, you can download public ones form steam as well so you are getting much more content from the game.

29454951.review:
An interesting and fun game - I'm sure it has been said before, but it reminds me of a bit more cerebral sidescrolling Hotline Miami crossed with the art style of Gunpoint and Risk of Rain.  

Stealth is more important than Hotline Miami, but action shooting is still possible, just riskier.  You essentially enter a map, can see basically all of it, will generally know how enemies will react, and must figure out an appropriate strategy to kill all the enemies without taking a scratch yourself.  As the game progresses, every few stages a new element, weapon, hazard, etc, will be introduced - the scale of difficulty and understanding of what you encounter is handled quite well I thought.

Control wise, the general aiming is mostly good.  It uses mouse to aim, as in with a cursor, and keyboard to move.  I feel like designing some elements of this with a gamepad in mind may have worked out better - in particular, I found it annoying how it can be difficult to reasses your aim when you change floors.  Another major annoyance - there's a single interaction button which handles flipping switches, opening doors, and picking up dropped weapons.  A number of times I was trying to do one of these actions and not others, particularly when I kill an enemy by a light switch.  

Graphically, the style is simple and works.  The light effects and atmosphere work.  It's  a functional but not gorgeous game.

Good soundtrack, effective effects.

Length of the game is good, gameplay is fun.  It's a good all-around game.

8/10.

Deadbolt est un jeu d'action/infiltration frénétique et exigeant. 
Développé par les créateurs de Risk of Rain, Deadbolt nous met dans la peau d'un tueur à gage/détective chargé d'enquêter sur les agissements de zombies et d'éliminer les cibles qui lui sont assignées. Le jeu pose efficacement son ambiance, grâce à une bonne direction artistique et une très jolie bande-son. Le gameplay est simple mais exigeant et le jeu prend des airs de die&retry, parfois frustrant cependant : le joueur enchaîne les tentatives jusqu'à planifier la méthode qui lui convient pour réussir chaque niveau. Seul bémol : on se prend facilement à profiter des failles du gameplay et de l'IA ce qui enlève un peu de saveur au jeu.

Got this through the humble bundle, was actually looking forward to it because I enjoyed Risk of Rain so much, but never really noticed that it came out.

Game is good, gameplay is solid, if very short, while I would still recommend it I'm haunted by a couple flaws.

Stealth killing is very inconsistent. Unless you throw a knife at someone, it's a coin toss whether hammering/knifing/shooting at someone will alert everyone else. This makes some levels very inconsistent, especially when it takes a few tries to beat them, especially in hardmode.

Some mob AI is pretty bad. If you take cover and there are two gunners, they'll shoot at you nonstop with infinite ammo, making your cover useless and you die the instant you peek. Other mobs do random things like the engineer enemy will place literally infinite mines if left unattended or the male vampires are somehow sharp shooting gods if they're still on the cieling.

Lastly weapon variety is lacking, it sort of makes sense because you pick up guns on the way, but I expected the shop atleast to offer me a sledgehammer or weapon upgrades, there's no real reason to use most of the weapons in the shop, Death & Taxes is probably the best one and I didn't even realize it until I beat the game.

Overall, great game, a little disappointingly short considering the playtime I got out of Risk of Rain, but enjoyable if INCREDIBLY frustrating at points.

29334264.review:
A solid, challenging bloodbath.  You're killing the undead so it's okay.

DEADBOLT is a 2D twitch puzzle game about violence.  It is a twitch game because it requires constant, split-second timing; and it's a puzzle game because your main challenge is not fighting, but determining your order of operations and tool selection.  You have a small number of weapons to choose from at the start of each level, and from there you have to kill your way to acquiring more weapons or ammunition to make it possible to proceed.

The format is "sink or swim", and "quick and dirty".  There are no checkpoints or game saves available while playing a level, and a single hit from any enemy will kill you.  If you slip up and get nailed, you start over.  A successful run will take maybe two minutes at most, but I found some levels punishingly difficult to crack, while others were beatable on the first or second try.  This led to my spending less than five minutes each on many levels, with a few taking much longer - one level took me almost an hour of retries to complete.

Some levels have many branching paths, circular paths, and alternate entrances.  Others are more linear.  This unpredictability serves to keep things fresh as each new level demands critical examination.

There is a good variety of enemies, each with their own special rules and behavior.  A certain kind of zombie might keep its head on the mantel, giving you an opportunity to kill it without confronting the body at all; a vampire couple might investigate a noise by approaching from the ceiling instead of walking on the floor.  Naturally, each enemy has his own attack type as well, some being more dangerous up close and others carrying long-range weaponry.  It is up to the player to learn all these rules through trial and error, and plan accordingly or adapt on the fly as a run unfolds.

I like the art style and love the music.  Duncan Drummond and Chris Christodoulou have done it again.

The minimal story is suitably creepy and pretty weird.  Although the game features vampires and zombies, it's definitely not a standard Halloween show.  The protagonist is a "reaper" (not [i]the[/i] Reaper, just [i]a[/i] reaper, whatever that means) who takes his orders from ... fire.  The setting is largely familiar, but with enough of the unfamiliar to be unsettling.  The mystery of what the undead are up to doesn't end up making a lot of sense from a human perspective, which I'm down with.  It's all an excuse to shoot monsters anyway.  But ... I appreciate the effort they took to make it strange and a bit poetic.

The game is short.  I clocked about 9 hours to get through all the missions.  There are also achievements and challenges, and completing them unlocks more weapons for your arsenal - if perfecting your strategies sounds like a good time, you could easily triple your hours.  Personally, although I may return some day to try to "5 star" all the missions, or try the Hard difficulty, I found myself perfectly satisfied with simply completing the story.  Again, the game is short, but every moment is solid gameplay, no filler.  I'd say the list price of $10 is a bargain.  To me this is a $15 game.

Il n'existe pas de jeu parfait, car on peut toujours trouver à redire, mais ce jeu s'approche tellement du sans-faute qu'il est difficile de mettre une moins bonne note.

La musique tout simplement parfaite, totalement en accord avec le jeu et originale, la direction artistique qui transporte avec un style en pixel art extrêmement bien maitrisé qui plonge dans l'univers du jeu, la difficulté qui augmente jusqu'à un niveau qui saura satisfaire les plus hargneux, la possibilité de speedrun le jeu (encouragé par le jeu) et du scoring, un gameplay précis et efficace, avec une bonne variété d'armes : en allant du simple revolver indémodable au shotgun bien bruyant, en passant par le sniper et la faux donnant satisfaction à chaque coup... Je ne trouve pas de défaut au jeu comme ça, mis à part qu'on en veut toujours plus.

Pour un prix comme ça (en soldes ça devient ridicule), il n'y a pas trop à réfléchir, c'est une excellente expérience vidéoludique, tout simplement.

29299587.review:
Deadbolt comes at a surprise. At first it feels like a pretty barebones (no pun intended) side scrolling one health shoot-em-up, but when you get into it it remains a barebones side scrolling one health shoot-em-up only a lot harder.

Playing as a no-named Reaper, your job is to kill the colorful assortments of undead who live in a sort of purgatory in reality. They hate it and want to move onto the next world, but they live here because they deserve it in some cosmic sense. So you just have to make sure that they don't do anything illegal and are punished SEVERLY for it. What this means is you have a large assortment of enemies to learn and deal with as they appear. They don't stay for too long as the game is only 30 missions and every faction has 10 of those missions. Some barely stay at all and appear for a couple missions before vanishing entirely. But the variety is very welcome as - as I said earlier - the game is pretty barebones.

As the game progresses you'll be able to grab additional weaponry to assist in your killing sprees while the game also gets steadily more difficult leading to the point where you're dying three or four times each stage at minimum to complete it. What's great is the difficulty is a very steady curve, there's never a point where you feel like the game just suddenly got too hard or too easy, it's a steady increase. It leads to the point where I spent about 40 minutes on the last level in a game where each level is 5 minutes at most typically. And that's not even getting into Hard mode.

While the premise is simple, it's a premise that works well, adding and removing a few layers of complexity along the way for whenever the mood needs it the most. All the while you have a pretty heavy soundtrack playing in the background keeping to the noir-ish theme of the game. Deadbolt plays and feels like a great game, personally I feel like it's missing a few things here and there, but it plays well, ramps up when it needs to, and ends in a satisfying way. High recommendation at full price.

29281330.review:
This game, in my opinion, is amazing. Therefore this is going to be a very biased review. You play as a Rolls driving grim reaper, who is tasked to investigate undead activity at certain locations, and to kick them brutally back into the sweet embrace of death. These undead aren't just hanging around moaning and shuffling their feet however, they're getting involved in drug deals and running night clubs, and most of them are heavily armed.

Pros:
- Good story that unfolds satisfactorily
- Great character design
- Perfect level design and general gritty atmosphere
- Pixel graphics suit the game to a T
- Highly satisfying combat with large variety of weapons
- Unforgiving gameplay -- die in one shot if you don't execute your plan perfectly. A lot of people      are saying this is a negative, but I love it
- Can be highly tactical
- Really good music

Cons:
- Nothing.. I told you it was going to be biased


I also love that enemies and environment both change drastically throughout the game, so you don't get bored of seeing the same old zombies. Also all the weapons aren't immediately available; you get access to some much later in the game. It can get frustrating at times, but I found I was frustrated at myself for dying, never at the game itself. There are usually a few options when it comes to tackling an area, so if something's not working you can try a different tactic.

This is the first Steam review I've ever written, which should tell you something about how much I enjoyed this game. 

BUY IT NOW!!

29278901.review:
Aside a few bugs and focus on trial-and-error gameplay, Deadbolt is a pretty solid little title similar somewhat to Gunpoint, mixing action, stealth and many gameplay mechanics. The setting, although only revealed in glimpses, is also quite fresh despite dealing with the world of the dead- a mixture of Buffy the Vampire slayer and the Punisher, where the protagonist is tasked by a mysterious force to kill undead gangs, vampiric triads and demonic mafiosi while searching for the truth behind the 'Ash' trade.

*POSITIVES*
- Variety of challenge and levels, different enemies requiring not only a steady gunhand but also wits
- Interesting world premise
- Entertaning and challenging
- Player level support

*NEUTRAL*
- Very limited ammo. Good for survival horror and stealth, but begs a question that if this Reaper is going about killing otherwordly mobsters, he'd have the foresight to supply with multiple clips of munitions, instead of relying blindly on on-site-procurement every single time. He isn't Solid Snake, after all.

*NEGATIVES*
- Gun trunk mechanics make no sense. Granted, I can understand the dev didn't want the PCs being able to just run back and forth between their trunk to resupply for different weapons, but throwing a knife and then being denied access is silly.
- Despite advertising itself as 'Choose your playstyle' game, some levels really leave you little choice other than to run in the door and let loose some deadly lead into your foes, as much as you'd love to tiptoe around the guards and perform the perfect Mr. 47-like execution of your target.
- Some levels are just bad in the sense you have to fail and fail again until you understand the timing and enemy movements. One notorious example is one nightclub where you have to destroy certain objects in the span of 60 seconds.
- Weapon store is limited, with half the weapons being a waste of precious souls. Why buy a 9 mm pistol when you get better drops almost instantly in the game. Better off just buying a suppressed shotgun and if you're feeling like throwing money around, the Scythe. Also, there's a multitude of weapons which do not make an appearance in the store, even 'tho they do ingame.
- Repetitive soundtrack.

*FINAL VERDICT*

If you enjoy some light stealth and are not averse to trial-and-error gameplay, this might be your game. A solid 6 or 7, considering the replayability with Hard Mode and player generated content. Should prolly pick it up in a sale if you're interested.

29278483.review:
This game is good, but it's not as good as it thinks it is.

When you die, a lot of times it's not because you could've prevented it, but the game likes to think that it's Dark Souls and that the solution to every problem is 'git gud'. You'll die, and a tip will pop up and be like "Oh hey you died, maybe you should try using cover next time?" ignoring the fact that cover is a useless mechanic in this game, on top of which it's a largely moot point in most situations because you died in a corridor with no cover available whatsoever. Likewise, another tip that comes up is varying forms of "Try a different way to complete the level", which is just about the most useless tip you could possibly give a player, especially when a lot of times there is objectively only one way to complete a level.

Man I'd really like to get the drop on these guys over here, if only the last five levels started with anything except a room with one or more bad guys and no workaround or vent from which to bypass or any way to sneak past or anything. Literally your only option is to go head-first into it and hope the mechanics are on your side this time.

And you'll be doing that a lot. Like, *a lot*. The majority of times that you die past the first section of levels, it's not because you didn't know what you were doing. It's because there's a mechanic that introduces randomness or otherwise something that you can't control or predict for, and if you misjudge the specific manner in which this mechanic will operate on this particular run, you're dead, try the whole level over again.

For instance, there's an enemy type that's a big melee skeleton guy, and he's got a sledgehammer. And by this point you've swung a sledgehammer in the game before, you know it's got a delay to it, so you can assume they'll have to deal with the delay in the same way you did. But they don't, and the way that you find out that they don't is that you die to it. Repeatedly. Inconsistently. Because their attack animation is them spinning around, and the point at which the spin becomes a hit can be anywhere from a half second afterward to the instant they see you. You can use the scythe to dash past them, but they sometimes - not all the time - hit you when you're behind them. So if it were consistent you'd be able to start from in front of them and go dash-attack/dash-attack/turn-around/dash-attack for a triple-slash combo that would feel good and dodge their first hit with the first or second dash. But since their mechanics are so unpredictable, you just have to do it and hope it works. Which wouldn't be so bad if it not-working once didn't mean you had to start all over again.

You'll play a level and it'll go one way, then replay it - usually because you died - and the part you got past will play out a different way for no discernible reason. You get in an elevator and go up, the guys on the floor don't do anything - rightfully so, there's a door in the way, they can't see or hear anything you're doing. But if you happen to accidentally kill a guy and knock his corpse into the elevator, then they'll somehow know something is up, so now they're activated and the area plays out a whole different way because you have to accommodate this new development, which normally in a game would be interesting but the whole point of a game like this is for you to be able to robotically complete it quickly and accurately if you know exactly what to do when the things that are supposed to happen. happen.

And the manner in which you go about killing people is another inconsistent mechanic that works against you. Sometimes you'll pick up a gun and it'll be normal - you'll shoot and it'll hit one guy. Other times, you'll pick up a different gun and it'l be able to pierce enemies in a line. Which is useful! Unfortunately there's no way to know which gun does that, so you can't plan on it whatsoever. And even if you could, you probably shouldn't, because shooting a hallway of guys all at once is a great way to get yourself killed, unless you can kill them all in one shot.

Which leads me to my next complaint: Automatic weapons are pointless in this game. If it's not a shotgun or a powerful pistol, there's just no point to it. Standing there unloading an entire clip into a guy is just asking for him or another guy behind him to shoot you in the face. The only way to effectively get shit done is to pop one or two rounds out and then run away if that didn't kill them. And by "run away" I mean go down the stairs and wait for them to chase after you.

The aforementioned 'cover mechanic': As said, it's useless. If you're having an open firefight with someone, you've fucked up. It might be helpful if you could shoot from behind cover, but you can't. You expose your entire body when you aim, which defeats the entire point of being behind cover.

Early on in the game you get a sense of freedom, of having many different options available to you. You can go through this vent, you can go through that one, you can go through this door and kill this guy, you can knock on the door to distract him, etc. And then progressively as you get further into the game, in an effort to make it seem harder (read: more frustrating) your options are narrowed down smaller and smaller. Vents now have valves that make it so you can't go through them without opening the valve first, preventing you from bypassing the room with the valve in it, kind of defeating the point of having a vent in the first place. Where they used to spider out into multiple exits, now each individual vent entrance will usually only have one exit point, and it's usually only right over there, next to the door you could've just walked through, both of which plant you in front of the enemy's line of sight. So again, what's the point.

As I said, the game is good. It's not great, it's not fantastic, it's not nearly as tight and reliable as it wants you to believe. But it's good. And you get a cat. Which is nice.

Just don't go in expecting it to be fair and you should be fine.

Do you like Risk of Rain ? Do you like Gunpoint ?

If you've answered yes to one (or both) of these questions then you're sure to love Deadbolt.

You are The Reaper, and you're here to take down the undead cartels. Sneak inside their warehouses and clubs and take them out one by one with hammers, knives, shotguns and the obligatory Reaper's Scythe. The game offers smooth gameplay, interesting characters, a unique concept, beautiful pixel art and an amazing soundtrack by yours truly Chris Christodoulou (he made Risk of Rain's soundtrack). 29187034.review:
DEADBOLT is an action game from somewhere in the overlap of Gunpoint and Hotline Miami. It's tightly designed and very fun to play, but I'd like to take a second to highlight how gorgeous the game is. Every faction in this weird, eldritch Place has its own unique aesthetic. 

The first enemies you face, the Zombies, are gangsters dressed in green and grey. There's a unit that uses a 9mm pistol, a unit with a backwards baseball cap and no shirt who attacks you with a tire iron, and a gigantic Bouncer that holds his sawed-off shotgun upside-down. Zombie levels are set in dilapidated motels and trailers containing meth labs. It's all very grungy and menacing.

I won't spoil the other factions, because it's a real joy to see them for the first time. They're all mechanically different as well, using different weapons and tactics, so every level is a different experience. This game is available in the Humble Bundle at the time of writing. So what are you waiting for?

29185740.review:
Tldr: A good game with the graphic style of Gunpoint and the gameplay more like Hotline Miami that is ultimately for me dragged down a considerably fair amount by several constant inconsistencies, making it a combination of trial and error and luck.

I haven't seen a game inconsistent to this degree in a long time. Sometimes a shotgun bouncer won't be one-shotted by my silenced shotgun if all the pellets don't connect with his chest correctly. I've even put two direct shotgun rounds into a hellhound and it didn't kill it while every other time before that the same dog died with one shot. Sometimes what should've been a direct perfectly aimed headshot kill won't be.Basically the game has often inconsistent hitboxes. Once in a while I can be screwed during a mission because a guy that takes several shots when I have one or two rounds left will have been alerted and stand right in front of the door I need to come out of and won't move so I just have to restart the level.

The game is often very difficult for the wrong reasons, forcing a ton of restarts on a lot of levels. The next-to-last vampire level took me 103 tries and the last vampire level took me 91 tries. I mean that is just breath takingly aggravating but what keeps me playing is that the gameplay is rock solid and really fun. When it works correctly that is. That's this game's biggest downfall is that because it is so inconsistent it requires a string of correctly timed moves combined with an equal amount of luck. The game's constant and heavy inconsistency causes huge amounts of maddening aggravation. Maybe other people have better luck. I think Hotline Miami is a harder game but I've had to restart levels in this game way more than I did in HM 1 or 2.

I love the graphics, sounds, music, and gameplay very much, but end up getting extremely aggravated by how reliably unreliable it is.

6/10 catch on sale. It is also pretty short, around 3-4 hours of actual gameplay, double that if I counted all of my retries.

29128300.review:
Imagine, for a second of Gunpoint and Hotline Miami had a baby, only Gunpoint was seeing Not a Hero on the Side and got a little of its structure thrown into the mix, then the baby came out with a gothic horror inspired skin. That's pretty much what you get with Deadbolt.

You are a Reaper. Your job is to eliminate a recent undead uprising, and only a few levels in, you discover the undead are using a new drug called Ash, which makes them feel alive. You are given increasingly more challenging missions from The Flame- literally a fireplace that talks to you. You work your way through the ranks, from low level zombies to mid level vampires, to even more that I won't spoil.

Even though you're a reaper, you're extremely vulnerable. Like, one hit from just about any weapon at all will kill you and send you back to the beginning of the level. This, and the gore are where the Hotline Miami genes come in. You can play recklessly thanks to the ease with which the game respawns you. The Gunpoint comes from the fact that you can be stealthy. Not only are shadows your best friends since they make it much more difficult for enemies to see you, but you can turn into smoke and travel through any given ventilation system. Each mission has a different objective, but generally speaking you'll be killing everything you can.

This is, obviously, a very different game than Hopoo game's previous work, the stellar Risk of Rain, which is an absolute blast to play solo or co op. This game only shows that the developers know what they're doing and can design many different kinds of games- which, personally, has me excited for whatever their next project is. All the mechanics in the game are fine tuned so that when you screw up and die, it's almost always your fault (although the AI will sometimes behave unpredictably and that can lead to a death that feels cheap). The level design is absolutely top notch. The game looks great. It sounds great. It plays great.

My only complaint with it is that the story is woefully under written. You're thrown into this situation with little in the way of exposition. I understand that being cryptic helps the atmosphere, but I would have liked to know a bit more of the lore behind the world. It's clear that it's there, it's just tough to piece out, which leads to an ending that feels a bit anti climactic from a story perspective.

But that shouldn't hold you back from playing this terrific game. If you're a fan of Hotline Miami, Gunpoint, Not a Hero, or just gothic horror in general, this absolutely needs to be on your must play list.
